bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Carey Addison is a PhD candidate at the Department of Urban and Public Affairs, University of Louisville. He also serves as the project evaluator for homeless housing projects at the Family Health Centers of Louisville. His areas of specialization include homelessness, affordable housing, and land use planning.

Sumei Zhang is an Assistant Professor at the Department of Urban and Public Affairs, University of Louisville. Her areas of specialization include comparative land-use management, urban dynamics, and policy evaluation.
Bradley Coomes is at Department of Urban and Public Affairs, University of Louisville, Louisville.

abstract.p: This bibliography focuses on the dynamic relationships between housing affordability for the low- and moderate-income (LMI) population and smart growth management and planning practices. Smart growth advocates generally seek to promote greater housing affordability and diversity. However, compact development, a goal of smart growth, curbs land development and poses significant challenges to promoting affordability. Housing markets can be affected by smart growth-related planning practices, ranging from growth management policies to various urban design tools such as transit-oriented development and urban infill. The review concludes by emphasizing several important social, administrative, and economic issues facing a successful integration of smart growth and affordable housing goals, and discusses possible solutions for maintaining affordability.

sec.title: I. Introduction
sec.p: As the dual agendas of curbing suburban sprawl and preserving a viable, yet affordable, housing market have become high-priority issues (Downs 2005), it is increasingly important to understand how they interact. The intent of this literature review is to provide a synthesis of the scholarship pertaining to the effects of growth management on housing, with a particular emphasis on affordability for low- and moderate-income (LMI) households. This body of research comes from different academic disciplines (such as economics, planning, geography, and sociology), covering issues such as land prices, home values, affordability, construction trends, and racial and ethnic exclusion. This article reviews recent publications specifically relevant to the impacts of growth management on housing affordability, providing a framework for evaluating the dynamics between modern planning practices and the complexities of the US housing market, and emphasizing the government’s role in maintaining affordability and promoting social equity.

The article is organized into four sections. Section I introduces the concept of smart growth, discusses common smart growth practices in urban planning and public policy, and analyzes the potential impacts of these practices on housing affordability. Many of these practices may decrease housing affordability, especially for LMI populations, and lead to social equity issues such as gentrification, displacement, and segregation. Therefore, it is critical to reevaluate these commonly adopted smart growth techniques in a more comprehensive framework, with simultaneous consideration of market conditions, innovative planning practices, and existing administrative and legal constraints. Section II provides reviews of 118 journal articles, five book chapters, and three PhD dissertations, with a focus on smart growth and housing affordability. Three criteria were used to select these works: (1) they are recent publications in academic journals, or recently published books or finished dissertations, (2) their topics are relevant to housing affordability and smart growth, and (3) they focus on or are relevant to practice in the United States, with most works based on US experiences and a few from other countries (Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom). Sections III and IV are author and keyword indices, making it convenient for readers to search for articles, book chapters, or dissertations.

sec.title: 1. The Evolution of Smart Growth
sec.p: Sprawl has been extensively studied. In the planning field, it has been agreed that sprawl is costly and creates various problems related to resource use, the environment, and personal health (Berke et al. 2006; Johnson 2001). In response to sprawl, planners have begun to use innovative techniques (e.g., transit oriented developments [TODs] and urban growth boundaries) to create more balanced and compact forms of development that are often referred to as “smart growth.” Smart growth promotes mixed-use, compact urban structure, walkability, more housing choices other than single family, and diversified transportation modes (Downs 2005; Ye, Mandpe, and Meyer 2005).

While these goals provide a basic framework for understanding smart growth, the concept can be difficult to define at both a practical and theoretical level. As efforts to mitigate the negative consequences of sprawl have grown in recent decades, the interpretation of the term smart growth can be both vague and easily manipulated by different growth agendas and interests (Ye, Mandpe, and Meyer 2005). Concurrently, the concept of sustainability has gained attention, and helps provide smart growth with some theoretical foundation. Different professions define sustainability differently, as it has many roots involving ecological, resource, economic development, and equity considerations (Kidd 1992). In the planning profession, the sustainability prism model (Berke et al. 2006) has gained acceptance, and provides a framework for understanding the multiple dimensions of sustainability. This model considers the trade-offs between the environment, the economy, and equity, and promotes development that is balanced across these three components. The concepts of smart growth and sustainability intertwine with each other in that the philosophy of smart growth is based on accommodating each of these factors. Smart growth practices have the common goal of achieving sustainable development, and smart growth can be interpreted as a development pattern balanced between environmental, economic, and equity considerations. With social equity being an important issue, promoting housing affordability for LMI populations is a common objective for smart growth practices. For instance, Ye, Mandpe, and Meyer (2005) study policies from various agencies, and find that nine of the ten documents listed housing among their primary goals, and seven specifically mentioned the implementation of affordable housing and greater housing variety.

The relationship between housing affordability and smart growth is complex. Many smart growth strategies are designed to promote affordability by increasing density, providing diversified housing options other than single-family units, and promoting better design with balanced distribution of work and residence (Downs 2005; Ye, Mandpe, and Meyer 2005). At the same time, in order to maintain environmental quality, many smart growth practices limit growth and reduce the supply of developable land (Downs 2005). These practices have the potential to increase housing prices and reduce housing affordability for LMI households. As the complexities of the relationship between smart growth and housing affordability have become increasingly visible, the academic literature has expanded to account for a wider spectrum of housing issues associated with various smart growth practices, including statewide growth management, urban growth boundaries, New Urbanism, urban revitalization, TOD, and open space preservation. This article reviews this broad range of literature to better understand how each of these smart growth elements affects housing affordability.

sec.title: 2. Common Smart Growth Management Practices
sec.p: Statewide growth management, urban growth boundaries, and impact fees represent common regulatory tools used by various levels of governments, exerting direct or indirect impacts on the housing market in a city or region. New Urbanism, TOD, and urban infill/revitalization are often piecemeal planning practices taking place at the neighborhood level. Impacts of these practices on housing affordability and social equity have been extensively studied (Pendall 2000; Ihlanfeldt 2004). In addition, there is a significant amount of literature that highlights the impacts of open space preservation on housing prices and affordability (Acharya and Bennett 2001; Irwin 2002).

Statewide growth management efforts cover large geographic territories and represent a state-sponsored control of development over a region. Some states, such as Florida, Maryland, Oregon, and Washington, have implemented various degrees of statewide growth management policies. These management systems vary across states, but with the same key focus of achieving a balance between socioeconomic, political, and environmental considerations (Carruthers 2002; Anthony 2003, 2006). Such practices likely hinder the availability of alternative growth locations and can have state-wide implications on housing markets (Carruthers 2002; Anthony 2003). These policies are generally criticized for lacking an explicit emphasis on housing, regulatory consistency, 1 local and regional collaboration, and effective policy tools to meet housing needs (Anthony, 2003; Boyle and Mohamed, 2007). Furthermore, there is virtually unanimous agreement on the need for states to better integrate explicit housing affordability goals into their growth management plans (Carruthers 2002; Boyle and Mohamed 2007; Anthony 2006).

An urban growth boundary (UGB) contains an officially designated area for development, and restricts development outside the boundary. It is one of the most extensively studied policy tools of growth management, and can take place at the state or at the local level. State-enforced UGBs (as in Oregon) reduce competitions between cities and provide stricter regulation on activities than a locally adopted UGB (as in Lexington, Kentucky; Woo and Guldmann 2011). An UGB itself often does not have a housing component. However, such a boundary directly restrains urban development within specific geographic borders, and therefore may restrict the supply of developable land, with indirect impacts on housing markets (Phillips and Goodstein 2000).

Impact fees, unlike UGBs, allow for development at any location, but require developers to make upfront payments to cover environmental and infrastructural costs. Such costs have the potential to be passed to housing consumers, therefore decreasing affordability. However, Burge and Ihlanfeldt (2006) claim that, if designed properly, impact fees can potentially enhance housing opportunity by including fee waivers and incentives for affordable and multifamily housing.

New Urbanism involves innovative principles, with a strong emphasis on compact development and mixed land uses, and has been considered an urban design tool capable of achieving smart growth goals (Bohl 2000; Larsen 2005). Planners hope that, by mixing housing types and minimizing transit costs, New Urbanism has the potential to better integrate affordable housing throughout communities. For example, it has been used to guide the implementation of public housing programs, such as HOPE VI (Talen 2002; Larsen 2005). However, producers of private housing have largely been unable or unwilling to include affordable housing within market rate developments, due to its limited marketability and profitability (Bohl 2000).

Transit oriented development (TOD) promotes compact urban development by improving the connection between homes and workplaces and by allocating residential and work places near public transit systems. Such practices improve site amenities by shortening commutes and reducing automobile reliance.

Urban revitalization and infill development encourage development and redevelopment activities within existing neighborhoods. It is a strategy with great potential to achieve more compact development and to improve housing opportunities within impoverished urban communities. Nevertheless, infill development often involves piecemeal practices. Because of other barriers (e.g., environmental contamination regulations, high costs, and consumer preferences), infill practices may be inappropriate for large-scale development (Farris 2001; Greenberg et al. 2001).

Open space preservation in urbanized regions has multiple purposes, preserving agricultural land, protecting ecosystems, and providing recreational amenities. This preservation involves a wide range of implementation challenges, including administrative tools, planning activities, and cooperation among governments. A very large amount of literature is available on this topic (Bolitzer and Netusil 2000; Acharya and Bennett 2001; Geoghegan 2001; Kaufman and Cloutier 2006). This article narrows the focus to works emphasizing the impacts of green space on housing prices and affordability.

sec.title: 3. Smart Growth and Housing Affordability
sec.p: The implementation of various smart growth tools can directly impact the supply–demand dynamics of the housing market, as theorized by Cooley and Lacivita (1982), and Engle, Navarro, and Carson (1992). Table 1 summarizes these impacts. On the supply side, urban growth boundaries and state-wide growth management may reduce the amount of developable land. As a result, housing supply may be reduced accordingly, and this will generate a negative impact on housing affordability. By excluding environmentally sensitive or rural areas from development, open space preservation will generate similar impacts on housing affordability.

caption.p: Theoretical Impacts of Growth Management on Housing Supply and Demand.

sec.p: When impact fees are introduced, housing production costs increase and developers may transfer these extra costs (including additional administrative cost and the impact fee itself) to home buyers (Evans-Cowley, Forgey, and Rutherford 2005; Burge and Ihlanfeldt 2006). Some empirical studies have shown that developers may build more expensive houses, because it is easier for them to transfer these costs (Burge and Ihlanfeldt 2006). Urban infill/revitalization practices often occur in existing neighborhoods, where it is costly to acquire land, remove existing structures, and possibly clean up contaminated sites. All of these factors increase housing construction costs.

Many growth control practices may have additional administrative costs. State growth management, urban growth boundaries, and open space preservation are often government-led growth management. Necessary administrative costs in the process of policy adoption and enforcement have been internalized into government budgets. New Urbanism, TOD, and urban infill/revitalization may take place in neighborhoods which are often regulated by traditional large-lot zoning practices. Administrative costs may occur during the rezoning process when converting a parcel from single-family to mixed-use development, which could be denied by a zoning commission because of the exclusionary nature of a traditional zoning ordinance. These costs may be transferred to homebuyers in the form of higher housing price.

On the demand side, state growth management and urban growth boundaries may indirectly control population levels by limiting developable land, and therefore may lead to a decreasing housing demand. But a declining housing demand does not necessarily mean improving housing affordability for the LMI population. Without an active fair share housing component in such a regional growth policy that restrict land provision and therefore housing supply, the market will naturally respond by providing more expensive houses to maintain profits. Thus, housing can be less affordable to the LMI population.

Both UGB policies and TODs promote compact urban form, often with convenient access to public transit systems. New Urbanism promotes mixed activities, and infill development often takes place in old neighborhoods with good accessibility. These practices tend to reduce transportation costs and increase residential amenities and, as a result, housing demand for these locations may increase. Housing prices may increase accordingly. Nevertheless, the impacts on affordability are dynamic. Increasing housing prices may lead to lower affordability. On the other hand, the lower transportation costs may exert a counteracting effect, because they may compensate for the added costs of housing, thus, improving overall affordability.

Growth management at the municipal or state level often promotes compactness and has the potential to achieve a more efficient allocation of activities across the city or region. This implies better accessibility to service activities (e.g., police and fire protection, education, retail and personal services). These improved amenities may increase housing prices. Similarly, the preservation of natural spaces in urbanized areas can add environmental and recreational amenities to neighboring locations, and increase house prices.

In summary, growth management practices tend to reduce land and housing supply, thereby increasing housing costs, and lowering affordability. On the demand side, growth management practices generate desirable amenities which improve the quality of life, but for which home buyers incur the costs. This will likely have the strongest impact on LMI households, who have the least ability to pay.

Table 2 summarizes empirical results of various studies analyzing the impacts of growth management practices on land values, housing prices, and housing affordability. Overall, these studies support the hypothesis that growth management practices have strong ramifications for the price and, consequently, the affordability of housing, as expected in Table 1. Empirical studies suggest that state growth management and UGBs tend to increase housing prices and lower affordability (Nelson 2000; Carruthers 2002; Downs 2002; Anthony 2003, 2006; Woo and Guldmann 2011). However, another group of scholars have suggested that other factors, such as regional trends, economic growth, and amenities, may be more influential in driving the escalation of housing costs (Phillips and Goodstein 2000; Jun 2006). Further, many other factors may escalate housing prices as well, such as in-migration, inflation, and supply–demand imbalance. UGBs do not necessarily inflict housing shortages and increase prices if boundary designations and expansion plans can keep pace with population growth and market trends (Knaap and Hopkins 2001; Carlson and Dierwechter 2007). Aurand (2010) notes that such regional level growth management often adopts multiple strategies to promote density, mixed land-use, and a variety of housing types, and concludes that there is a positive relationship between polices that promote density and housing variety and affordability.

sec.p: Impact fees could have varying impacts on housing prices and affordability, depending on the nature and stringency of the policy, as well as the elasticity of the market. Studies (Skidmore and Peddle 1998; Heim 2001; Burge and Ihlanfeldt 2006) have suggested that impact fees introduce additional administrative requirements and may be effective in slowing growth. For instance, requirements for expanded water and sewer capacity for multifamily housing will hinder such development because of lengthy application processes. Further, by requiring upfront compensation for potential pressures on existing infrastructure, impact fees could mitigate the high cost of infrastructure expansion, which otherwise will be endured by local governments. Impact fees can also perpetuate housing price increases, which often place the most severe burdens on LMI populations (Evans-Cowley, Forgey, and Rutherford 2005). However, Burge and Ihlanfeldt (2006) also suggest that non-water/sewer related (e.g., school and road) impact fees increase the development of multifamily housing, and may promote affordability for LMI households. Evans-Cowley, Forgey, and Rutherford (2005) conclude that impact fees could have opposite effects on land value, depending on whether the land has been developed and whether substitutable land is available.

New Urbanism principles have been implemented in housing developments in the United States, particularly developments that have received government subsidies or involved public–private collaborations (Bohl 2000; Larsen 2005). Studies of these projects focus on beneficiary groups, administration, and displacement (Tu and Eppli 1999; Song and Knaap 2003; Matthews and Turnbull 2007). In the private sector, developments inspired by New Urbanism, such as Kentlands, Maryland, have generally been shown to command higher prices than more traditionally designed neighborhoods. A survey conducted by Johnson and Talen (2008) shows that the private sector has been less motivated to pay any attention to the affordability issue and, without regulatory enforcement or financial incentives, private developers do not consider affordability, primarily for profitability reasons.

TOD promotes better linkages among daily activities by locating them near the public transit system. Proximity to transit lines and transit enhancements (both anticipated and completed) have been shown to generally raise land values and housing prices (Bowes and Ihlanfeldt 2001; Knaap, Ding, and Hopkins 2001; Cervero and Duncan 2002; McMillen and McDonald 2004; Debrezion, Pels, and Rietveld 2007; Kahn 2007). Increases in housing prices may motivate municipalities to promote TOD to obtain greater property tax revenues (Knaap, Ding, and Hopkins 2001; Cervero and Duncan 2002). Increasing property values suggest that TODs may present affordability barriers and gentrification threats for LMI groups (Kahn 2007).

Infill strategies have been noted to decrease housing value disparities and restore vitality to urban communities (Greenberg et al. 2001; Schill et al. 2002). However, they also spur gentrification and rent inflation (Schill et al. 2002; Steinacker 2003). Costs are the major barrier between this type of development and affordability. As indicated by Farris (2001) and based on his seventeen-year experience as a developer in St. Louis, the price of redevelopment of a square foot of land is estimated to be $15, as compared to $0.25 to $5 for previously undeveloped land. Ryan and Weber (2007) also conclude that redevelopment activities are more expensive. Steinacker (2003) based her study on the fifty largest metropolitan statistical areas in the United States, and finds that infill development leads to higher rents, and therefore, lower affordability.

Open spaces provide desirable environmental amenities. Available studies have consistently demonstrated the potential to increase housing prices (Bolitzer and Netusil 2000; Acharya and Bennett 2001; Kaufman and Cloutier 2006). Price appreciation is generally predicted to be contingent on the permanency of preservation efforts, with properties closer to permanent open space commanding higher premiums (Bolitzer and Netusil 2000; Geoghegan 2001; Irwin 2002). Redevelopment of open space has even been suggested as a potential community development tool for declining urban neighborhoods (Kaufman and Cloutier 2006). However, while such amenity enhancements may be beneficial for homeowners, they present negative implications for affordability issues facing other groups, such as LMI renters and homeowners.

sec.title: 4. Policy Implications
sec.p: In summary, many smart growth management techniques decrease housing affordability for LMI populations. Regulatory policies, including both new growth management techniques and traditional zoning practices, have been demonstrated to significantly contribute to the inflation of housing costs, and more heavily regulated areas offer less affordable housing for renters and LMI households (Carlson and Mathur 2004; Schill 2005). In addition to affecting housing affordability, growth management regulations generate several concerns relevant to displacement, gentrification, and other social equity issues. With affordability for LMI populations looming as a serious concern in US cities, it is necessary to reevaluate and redesign growth management practices, and to encourage comprehensive practices that simultaneously consider market issues, planning tools, and the role of government.

sec.title: Market profitability
sec.p: Thompson (2011) views the city as a “distorted” price system. At a certain level, this system protects the existing social relations and the corresponding political order. For instance, housing markets operate on a profit-driven price basis that reflects the preferences of high- and middle-income groups, while overlooking the basic needs of low-income populations. The market values profit much higher than improving social quality. As a result, developers do not voluntarily consider housing affordability. Available empirical studies confirm this conclusion (Table 2). Therefore, public interventions must continue to be taken to promote affordability in the market.

The Federal government plays a critical role in promoting public housing and affordability, using strategies such as (1) tax credits or subsidies to promote housing supply for eligible LMI households, (2) providing publicly owned or operated housing, and, (3) improving the competitiveness of LMI households in a housing market by providing vouchers (Schwartz 2010). Schwartz’s book reveals that the amount of public housing has been decreasing since the late 1990s and that most housing funded by tax-credit or voucher holders still remained in central, distressed, or minority neighborhoods, where LMI households are usually located. Beneficiaries’ income is often the primary concern when allocating tax credits, vouchers, and subsidies/grants. 2

Considerations of localities in housing-related policies may improve the efficiency for promoting affordability for LMI households in the market. Location-efficient mortgages, community housing incentives, housing trust funds, and community land trusts are good examples of ways to increase the ability of disadvantaged groups to compete in the housing market (Greenberg et al. 2001; Nelson 2000; Schwartz 2010). All these practices call for a further involvement of state and local governments in policy initiations and program designations to promote housing affordability for the LMI population. Some local policies, such as impact fees, congestion tolls, purchasable development rights, and the redesignation of property tax structures, reflect other avenues in increasing housing costs for dominant social groups (Gihring 1999; Brueckner 2000). In summary, government interventions are necessary, with a focus on improving the competitiveness of low-income groups. Localized management, instead of standardized regulation, considers local social and political norms, and therefore, may be more effective in promoting housing affordability.

sec.title: Planning practices
sec.p: How to promote affordability in planning practices has been extensively discussed (Pendall 2000; Glaeser and Gyourko 2002; Jun 2006; Talen 2008; Aurand 2010). First, planners should gradually shift the focus from traditional low-density zoning to innovative zoning. The traditional large lot zoning has been commonly accused as one reason for increasing housing prices. Many innovative practices have been recommended, such as inclusionary zoning, incentive zoning, high-density zoning, and smartcode. Second, many planning mechanisms have been implemented experimentally, such as brownfield redevelopment, urban infill, new urbanism, environmental zoning, and high-density zoning. Planners need to learn from these experiences. For instance, according to the literature (Jun 2006; Aurand 2010), high-density development and variety in housing consistently promote affordability for LMI populations and, therefore, such strategies should be promoted. However, the public may oppose such density-enhancing strategies (Danielsen, Lang, and Fulton 1999; Downs 2005). This possibility leads to the third action to promote better integration between education and practice from the planning profession. Planners need to be well educated and utilize innovative design strategies to make higher-density developments more attractive.

sec.title: Legal and administrative supports
sec.p: Zoning reform, redesigning the taxation structure, and fair-share housing policy adoption need support from local, state, and federal administrative structures. Some government-initiated programs have shown effectiveness in maintaining affordability. For instance, Montgomery County, Maryland, is one of the very few counties with increasing levels of rental affordability. This is because of Montgomery County’s implementation of the Moderately Priced Dwelling Unit Program, which combines density bonuses with preservation measures (Carlson and Mathur 2004). In addition, political fragmentation is another important issue to be dealt with by planners and policy makers. As noted by Boyle and Mohamed (2007), the absence of consistent and strong cooperation between governments has prevented affordability goals from being achieved. Legislative efforts at the state or federal level might be an answer. For instance, in England, the Town and Country Planning Act enforces a negotiation about affordable housing between developers and planners across the country. This can successfully eliminate different interpretations about affordability in different cities, and guarantees a share of affordable housing in every development.

The success of an integration of affordability in smart growth policy will require diligent application of data to study market trends, innovative practices from the planning area, and cooperation across governments, as well as between private and public sectors. With successful implementation of these concepts and formulation of new strategies, the goals of balanced growth and housing equity may be effectively recognized.

sec.title: A. Linking Smart Growth to Affordable Housing
sec.p:
1. Arman, M., J. Zou, L. Wilson, G. Zillante, and S. Pullen. 2009. “Challenges of Responding to Sustainability with Implications for Affordable Housing.” Ecological Economics 68 (12): 3034-41.
Keywords: Australia, sustainability
This article provides a literature review about the compatibility of sustainability and affordable housing in Australia. The authors analyzed conceptual and pragmatic challenges of sustainability. Conceptual challenges focus on the reasons for pursuing sustainability. Six reasons are listed, including separating needs from wants, sustainable consumption, environmental justice, the care for future generations, opportunity costs, and possible eternal poverty. Pragmatic challenges focus on how to achieve sustainability, as laid out by the authors, including too many interests, global inequity, a competitive market, and limited knowledge. The authors pointed out that sustainability is happening when people are debating about it. They also evaluated whether these challenges made sustainable housing attainable. They concluded that many of these challenges do not pose immediate threats to applying sustainable development to affordable housing. However, affordable housing in Australia has historically sought to address social and economic issues, not environmental issues. In Australia, sustainable housing practice has focused on the wealthy and is often designed by prestigious architects. The authors saw this paradigm of sustainability for the rich as the main obstacle for attaining sustainable affordable housing.
2. Chapin, T. S., and C. E. Connerly. 2004. “Attitudes towards Growth Management in Florida: Comparing Resident Support in 1985 and 2001.” Journal of the American Planning Association 70 (4): 443–52.
Keywords: Florida, growth management
This article uses survey data to examine how attitudes about growth management changed among Florida residents between the state’s 1985 inception of statewide growth management and 2001. Data were obtained as part of the 1985 and 2001 Florida Annual Policy Survey which yielded approximately 1,000 respondents for each of these years. Chi-square analysis is used to determine attitude differences across various demographic and economic groups as well as geographic regions. Between 1985 and 2001, the perceived need for growth management among respondents remained strong, but fell from 71.8 to 67.7 percent. Furthermore, supportiveness for governmental intervention in managing growth also fell by nearly 12 percentage points during this period. While attitudes toward growth management were distributed relatively evenly among demographic groups in 1985, the authors find that by 2001, perceived needs for growth control declined substantially in groups including blacks, Hispanics, males, and low- and moderate-income households. Meanwhile high-income and white households demonstrated an increase in perceived needs for growth control. The authors attribute these changes to factors including observed imperfections in the state’s policies, shifts in economic concerns, and changes in the political context. Enhancing public familiarity with growth management is recommended as an important step in maintaining support for growth management legislation.
3. Danielsen, K. A., R. E. Lang, and W. Fulton. 1999. “What Does Smart Growth Mean for Housing?” Housing Facts and Findings 1 (3): 1, 12–15.
Keywords: affordability, growth management, location efficient mortgage, smart growth
In this brief article, Danielsen et al. address the question of how smart growth and growth management can be successful without hampering housing affordability. As housing essentially dominates the built environment and growth management policies essentially restrict development, the authors emphasize the importance of understanding the impacts of growth management on affordable housing. Strategies for providing more affordable housing include higher density housing, the mixing of rental and owner occupied housing, and urban infill. Increasing flexibility of zoning, urban growth boundaries, and encouraging accessory dwelling units are suggested as viable planning mechanisms to meet these housing concerns. However, Danielsen et al. note that density enhancing strategies are likely to be met with opposition from the public, particularly in suburban areas. To overcome such challenges, the authors recommend a housing development pattern that blends urban style and suburban amenities to attract more affluent households. It is also noted that lending institutions are often hesitant about investing in areas with untested development strategies advocated by smart growth agendas. Solutions to this challenge include alternative financing strategies and sources as well as the development of secondary mortgage market tools.

list-item.p: 4. Downs, A. 2004. “Growth Management, Smart Growth, and Affordable Housing.” In Growth Management and Affordable Housing: Do They Conflict? edited by A. Downs. Washington, DC: The Brookings Institute.

sec.p: In this concluding chapter to Down’s collection of discussions on the relationship between smart growth and affordable housing, he states the goals of creating “a politically realistic prospective on the relationship between growth management, smart growth, and affordable housing” and he advocates for “a greater emphasis on affordable housing in future growth management and smart growth efforts.” Downs outlines the affordability problems of both impoverished and moderate income households. Many smart growth strategies have the potential of enhancing affordability, such as manufactured housing, multifamily housing, and accessory dwelling units. However, smaller houses have been prohibited by traditional land use tactics, such as zoning. Furthermore, the obstacles of homeowner interests to protect property values, public unwillingness to fund low-income housing, and municipal desires to maximize the monetary benefits of land uses have also hampered the provision of affordable housing. Therefore, although smart growth policies can include affordable housing goals, they usually do not because doing so has the likelihood of evoking public resistance. Downs concludes that the promotion of regional goals by coalitions of smart growth and affordable housing advocates, as well as state-supported policy, may serve as potential means for beginning to overcome such obstacles and making smart growth socially just.

list-item.p: 5. Downs, A. 2005. “Smart Growth: Why We Discuss It More than We Do It.” Journal of American Planning Association 71 (4): 367–78.
Keywords: smart growth, economic concerns, administrative inefficiency, legal constraints

sec.p: In this article, Downs provides an in-depth analysis about why smart growth has been well accepted, but is not effectively implemented. He identifies eight obstacles, which can be categorized into economic concerns, legal constraints, and administrative inability. Smart growth promotes compact development, which completely changes the current spatial distribution of benefits and costs associated with single-family low-density development. People are unwilling to take the economic risk. Homeowners may like the idea of increasing residential density, but actually oppose to introduce additional apartment homes to their own neighborhood to protect their property values. In addition, as smart growth restricts development outside developed areas, potential profits shift from new growth outside of cities to infill development inside cities. Further, with limited supply of land, housing prices will increase. All these hurt the economic benefits of outlying land owners, renters, and potential homeowners. Legislatively, most states follow the home rule, with local communities holding the power to regulate land use activities. With disjointed incrementalism being the dominant decision-making model, administrative costs increase quickly with more issues (e.g., economic and environment) considered. Further, in such a decentralized system, smart growth policy often fails in achieving expected outcomes. For instance, for the failure to reduce traffic congestion, it is actually related to a lack of regional view of traffic issue and a lack of cooperation between communities. At last, Downs analyzed the likelihood of implementation of different smart growth policy. He listed affordable housing as the only object that is unlikely to achieve. He pointed out that state governments should play more critical role in land-use management.

list-item.p: 6. Howell-Moroney, M. 2008. “A Description and Exploration of Recent State-Led Smart Growth Efforts.” Environment and Planning C: Government and Policy 26: 678–95.
Keywords: smart growth instruments, urban revitalization

sec.p: There are three goals of this article: to define smart growth, to summarize US smart growth efforts over 1998–2001, and to explain why certain states embrace smart growth policies. The author made clear distinction between growth management (a mainly state mandated comprehensive planning process) and smart growth (encompassing a much broader set of policies that until now have not seen widespread adoption-especially at the state level). Major smart growth instruments include urban revitalization, growth control, land preservation, housing, planning, and transportation. The author examined what states adopted these policies and to what extent, why these states adopted such policies, and possible relationships between different policy areas. A series of regression analyses (including logistic and Poisson models) were conducted. Results indicate that fast population growth is the most consistent predictor for a state adopting smart growth policies. States that practice urban-revitalization are more likely to enforce land preservation policies (and vice versa). Growth control and housing affordability policies are also positively associated.

list-item.p: 7. O’Connell, L. 2008. “Exploring the Social Roots of Smart Growth Policy Adoption by Cities.” Social Science Quarterly 89 (5): 1356–72.
Keywords: smart growth, education, environmental activism

sec.p: In order to test the hypothesis of whether education and environmental activism are the key factors promoting smart growth, O’Connell surveyed 340 cities across twenty-six states, with 59 percent response rate. Thirteen states have local planning requirement, and another thirteen are randomly selected as a control group. A smart growth involvement indicator was created based on number of policies adopted to control growth. Percentage of population with at least bachelor’s degree was used to represent education level. Another simple categorical variable with value 2, 1, or 0 represented the existence of smart growth and environmental activities groups, having one of those, or having none. The regression results confirmed the hypothesis. The survey data itself revealed some interesting reality about growth management. Infilled development, rehabilitation, and mixed-development zoning are the most common tools to regulate growth in all states, with or without planning requirement. In states with local planning requirement, more cities adopted policy to encourage transit-oriented development, green space preservation, urban growth boundary, transfer of development rights, and zoning for smaller lot size.

list-item.p: 8. O’Toole, R. 2001. “The Folly of ‘Smart Growth’: Oregon’s Experience Suggests ‘Anti-Sprawl’ Strategies Worsen the Problems They Are Intended to Solve.” Regulation 24 (3): 20–26.
Keywords: affordability, Portland (Oregon), single-family housing, smart growth, urban growth boundary

sec.p: O’Toole’s challenge to the smart growth agenda is based upon a case study of Portland which depicts a number of potentially undesirable effects. Traffic congestion, air pollution, increasing consumer costs and taxes, as well as the inflexibility of urban growth boundaries, are cited as negative externalities resulting from Oregon’s growth management policies. O’Toole notes that between the years of 1989 and 1996, Portland housing market transitioned from being one of the nation’s most affordable one to one of the least affordable. Higher density building requirements have helped create a mismatch in the housing market, evidenced by high apartment vacancies and sharp increases in single-family housing prices. To manage growth in ways that are more suitable to market preferences, O’Toole suggests free market solutions as an alternative to smart growth policies. These proposed alternatives include highway toll systems, pollution fees, and local level land use decisions which allow citizens to decide upon and fully pay for lifestyle choices.

list-item.p: 9. Talen, E., and J. Koschinsky. 2011. “Is Subsidized Housing in Sustainable Neighborhoods? Evidence from Chicago” Housing Policy Debate 21 (1): 1–28.

sec.p: Sustainability is often interpreted as diversity, accessibility, and walkability, which are attractive amenities of a neighborhood. In this sense, promoting sustainability will increase housing cost and reduce affordability. On another hand, affordability and sustainability could also be mutually supportive by reducing house size to achieve high-density development and by thoughtful design to maintain accessibility. The authors used Chicago as a case study, and investigated the relationship between sustainability and affordability. Eighteen variables (measuring locational amenities, pedestrian orientation, street design, density, and diversity) were used to quantify sustainability. Information about subsidized housing units (from five different projects, Land Trusts, CHA family, CHA Senior, LIHTC, Multi-family Subsidy, and Housing Choice Vouchers) was gathered to test whether areas with subsidized houses had the same level of sustainability as areas without such houses. Analyses were conducted at both the census tract and the block group level. Results indicate that, in general, neighborhoods with subsidized units tended to be more sustainable, more accessible, more pedestrian-oriented, denser, and with more diversified activities than neighborhoods without such projects. However, if focusing on housing choice vouchers, neighborhoods with such units tend to be less sustainable.

list-item.p: 10. Voith, R. P., and D. L. Crawford. 2004. “Smart Growth and Affordable Housing.” In Growth Management and Affordable Housing: Do They Conflict? edited by A. Downs. Washington, DC: The Brookings Institute.

sec.p: This discussion considers the impacts of smart growth on housing affordability. Because smart growth essentially reduces the supply of developable land, it is likely to lead to a decreasing stock of affordable housing. This is especially true if development is inclusive of only more land intensive types of development, such as single-family homes, but is not necessarily true for other housing types. Voith and Crawford argue that smart growth polices allow for an increase in the supply of less-intensive residential land uses, such as townhomes, thus making such housing more affordable. The authors also state that smart growth can benefit low and moderate-income groups, by lowering the costs of infrastructure, utilities, and commuting, as well as altering the distribution of employment opportunities. The authors convey that enacting smart growth polices will inevitably create winners (persons without preference for intensive housing) and losers (persons with strong attachment for large lot housing). Furthermore, effects on landowner and developers vary according to the type of policy and their preparedness to adapt to smart growth. Voith and Crawford state that appropriate smart growth policies will offer more gains than loses, and some gains may be redistributed through measures, such as purchasing development rights, to achieve more equitable outcomes for everyone.

list-item.p: 11. Ye, L., S. Mandpe, and P. B. Meyer. 2005. “What Is `Smart Growth' --Really?” Journal of Planning Literature 19 (3): 301–15.

sec.p: According to Ye et al., smart growth is an ambiguous concept and can be defined in various ways that are beneficial to different agendas and interests. Using policy documents from ten federal agencies, national organizations, and coalitions, the authors attempt to develop a comprehensive definition for smart growth. They further use this definition to analyze smart growth policies in the states of Kentucky and Georgia. Of the reviewed definitions, nine of the ten documents list housing in their primary goals, and seven specifically mention the implementation of affordable housing and/or greater housing variety. Housing is one of the six broad components (together with planning, transportation, economic development, community development, and natural resource preservation) of smart growth. In their analysis of state documents, the authors found that seven of the twenty-one state and local documents from Georgia and eighteen of the twenty-three from Kentucky included housing in their smart growth agendas.

sec.title: 1. State Growth Management
sec.p:
12. Anthony, J. 2003. “The Effects of Florida’s Growth Management Act on Housing Affordability.” Journal of the American Planning Association 69 (3): 282–94.
Keywords: affordability, displacement, Florida, growth management
Anthony’s study may be one of the first to discuss the effects of statewide growth management policy on housing affordability. Using two measures, a simple affordability index and a composite affordability index, his research extends beyond merely analyzing housing price. The time-series analyses suggest the affordability of single-family owner occupied homes in Florida was significantly reduced over 1980–1995 due to the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and the 1985 Land Development Regulation Act. While the Act required discussion of affordable housing in each local comprehensive plan, this goal was rarely actualized. Furthermore, because this policy is implemented at the statewide level, the dynamics of displacement are different in areas that only utilize local growth management policies, reducing the number of alternatives for displaced individuals. This article concludes with a discussion of potential ways to rectify this problematic aspect of growth management by requiring greater specificity and promoting greater levels of density in local comprehensive plans.

list-item.p: 13. Anthony, J. 2006. “State Growth Management and Housing Prices.” Social Science Quarterly 87 (1): 122–41.
Keywords: affordability, Florida, growth management, housing price, single-family housing

sec.p: This updated interpretation on Florida’s Growth Management Act (GMA) suggests significant impacts from GMA practices on single-family housing prices. The GMA seeks to maximize infrastructure and to curb the perpetuation of urban sprawl, through strong state implementation and administration. Because of anticipation of subsequent housing price inflation related to this act, affordable housing production efforts were also developed. To determine the effects of the GMA, Anthony conducted a time-series analysis based on 1980–1995 housing and policy data obtained from the Florida Statistical Abstract and Florida Office of Community Affairs. He demonstrates the statistical significance of the proposed price increases due to the GMA’s adoption. Initial price increases due to the GMA’s adoption was $1,219 per home, and $1,002 for each year thereafter. Thus, Anthony states that Florida’s affordable housing programs have failed to counteract the effects of the GMA. To insure affordability and continued support of the program, Anthony proposes that efforts should be made to reduce the scarcity of affordable housing by minimizing production cost effects, keeping markets competitive, and increasing affordable housing production.

list-item.p: 14. Carruthers, J. I. 2002. “The Impact of State Growth Management Programmes: A Comparative Analysis.” Urban Studies 39: 1959–82.
Keywords: affordability, growth management, land value

sec.p: This study analyzes the effects of statewide growth management programs in 238 US metropolitan counties between 1982 and 1997. Effects are defined in terms of density, extent of urbanized land areas, public infrastructure expenditures, population change, and property value. Noting the importance of property value on subsequent housing prices and affordability, Carruthers explores the relationships between growth management and land value. The link between property value and density is shown to be positive. Carruthers also makes a unique contribution to the literature by considering the effects of property values on population change. If land values escalate, certain (low- and moderate-income) groups will be consequently priced out of the market and forced to live in another area. Evidence of differences between state polices suggest that the promotion of horizontal and vertical consistency among state growth management programs as well as proper inclusion for new development can minimize such negative effects.

list-item.p: 15. Dawkins, C. J., and A. C. Nelson. 2002. “Urban Containment Policies and Housing Prices: An International Comparison with Implications for Future Research.” Land Use Policy 19: 1–12.
Keywords: Boulder (Colorado), California, greenbelt, Oregon, housing price, South Korea, statewide policy, United Kingdom

sec.p: This article reviews an international sampling of research on urban containment policies and housing from the United Kingdom, South Korea, and the United States. In the United Kingdom where greenbelts have been nationally mandated since 1947, studies have suggested that the land supply has been affected with the consequence of disproportionately high housing prices. In the South Korean city of Seoul, which has had a greenbelt since 1971, social costs are noted to exceed benefits in the long run if periodic revisions to the green belt boundary are not made. In the United States, statewide policies in Oregon and California are considered, as well as local containment programs, such as Boulder, Colorado’s greenbelt. In these cases, the design and implementation of policies as well as the dynamics of the economy and housing market are all noted as relevant factors in determining changes in housing prices. Dawkins and Nelson also provide a critique of existing research, stating that an overreliance on the hedonic model has not adequately captured supply side effects. It is noted that an abundance of case studies on this topic make meta-comparisons, such as this study, possible but place limits on the research’s ability to make broad generalizations.

list-item.p: 16. Dawkins, C. J., and A. C. Nelson 2003. “State Growth Management Programs and Central-City Revitalization.” Journal of the American Planning Association 69 (4): 381–97.

sec.p: In this article, Nelson and Dawkins conducted a time-series analysis about the impacts of state growth management programs on urban development, focusing on the effects that channel growth back into central cities and divert it away from urban fringes and outlying suburbs. They use rates of new residential constructions in central city to determine revitalization development for 293 metropolitan statistical areas across the nation with or without state mandated growth management. The authors conclude that metropolitan areas in states with growth management programs have demonstrated marginally enhanced opportunities for central city residential development.

list-item.p: 17. Deal, B., J. H. Kim, and A. Chakraborty. 2009. “Growth Management and Sustainable Transport: Do Growth Management Policies Promote Transit Use?” Journal of Public Transportation 12 (4): 21–40.
Keywords: state growth management, public transit

sec.p: The goal of this article is to examine the effects of state growth management policy on transit mode choice, using Florida, Maine, Maryland, New Jersey, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Washington as case studies. The authors’ study is based on a 2005 American Community Survey about the percentage of people living in old housing (built before 2000) and living in new housing (built between 2000 and 2005), as well as the commuting activities of them. Two strategies of growth management could effectively promote public transit use: (1) regulating city core abandonment and (2) directing new development into areas where transit systems already exist. Using additional data from the Public Use Microdata Samples and the US Census Bureau decennial census of 2000, the authors studied the change in the percentage of commuters that use transit over 2000–2005, occupancy rates, and new development. Results indicate that state growth management policies do promote transit use.

list-item.p: 18. Frece, J. W. 2004–2005. “Twenty Lessons from Maryland’s Smart Growth Initiative.” Vermont Journal of Environmental Law 6 (2): 106–32.
Keywords: affordability, displacement, gentrification, Maryland, priority funding areas, Rural Legacy Act, smart growth

sec.p: This review focuses on the smart growth legislation in Maryland and depicts a number of both positive and negative outcomes of the state’s Priority Funding Areas (PFA) program and Rural Legacy Act (RLA), which were designed to promote contiguous development in developed landscapes and to discourage development in undeveloped areas. Some positive attributes of the program include the program’s ability to work within political realities, to provide incentives for compliant development, to unite urban and rural interests, and to provide education to pave the way for cultural change. However, Freece also notes shortfalls, such as a lack of specific goals, insufficient public input and visioning, and inadequate financial incentives to alter development patterns. Furthermore, the program did not raise enough housing concerns, especially shortages of moderate-income housing in the increasingly expensive Baltimore–Washington region. New urbanist redevelopment strategies also present threats of gentrification, out-pricing, and consequent displacement of the low-income residents of revitalized urban areas. While Freece commends the Maryland initiatives as being a positive step in effectively controlling growth, he states that stronger incentives and more integrated planning efforts are essential for the goals of smart growth to be met.

list-item.p: 19. Shen, Q., and F. Zhang. 2005. “Land-Use Changes in a Pro-Smart-Growth State: Maryland, USA.” Environment and Planning A 39: 1457–77.
Keywords: Maryland, priority funding areas, Rural Legacy Act, smart growth

sec.p: This study serves as an evaluation of policies that have been enacted through Maryland’s 1997 statewide smart growth legislation, which includes two key initiatives, priority funding areas (PFAs) and rural legacy areas (RLAs). PFAs target certain areas for higher density development through incentives and RLAs are intended to protect certain areas from development. Noting that these policies carry no regulatory power, Qing and Zhang raise the research question of how effective they have been in meeting their goals. To answer this question, a longitudinal analysis of land conversion and a cross-sectional comparison of land conversion among eight counties are conducted. The 1992 National Land Cover Data of US Geographical Survey was used, along with 1997 and 2002 land cover data from the Maryland Property View database, to determine the extent of development within the RLAs and PFAs, before and after adopting the smart growth legislation. Findings suggest that land in PFAs is more likely to be developed after the passage of smart growth legislation, while RLAs are less likely to be developed. While stating that these results confirm a general success of the program, the authors also note differences among counties that are attributed to differing physical, socioeconomic, and political environments. State and local collaborations are proposed as important components of future success.

sec.title: 2. Urban Growth Boundaries
sec.p:
20. Aurand, A. 2010. “Density, Housing Types and Mixed Land Use: Smart Tools for Affordable Housing?” Urban Studies 47 (5): 1015–36.
Keywords: density, mixed housing types, mixed land uses, housing price, affordability
In this article, Aurand provided good theoretical discussions about how density, mixed housing types, and mixed land use would impact house price and affordability. He simplified housing markets into two submarkets, affordable and nonaffordable market. Density is expected to increase house prices in both markets. Variety of housing types will increase nonaffordable housing prices, while it has very limited impact on the price of the affordable housing. Mixed land use may have greater impacts on an affordability housing market by increasing price. In order to test these hypotheses, Portland and Seattle were used over 1990–2000 as the case studies. Portland had an urban growth boundary over the period, while Seattle did not have one until the mid-1990s. Therefore, Aurand claimed that this created a quasi-experimental design. An index of housing type diversity (that is similar to Shannon diversity index) was calculated. Residential density was directly represented as housing units per square mile. The mixture level of land use activities was measured by the balance between amount of residents and amount of service jobs. These variables, together with a set of control variables, were used as independent variables to explain the variations in percentage of affordable units, number of affordable units, and number of nonaffordable units. Results indicate that residential density and variety of housing types did increase affordability. Mixed land use had very limited impact. Urban contain policy did not affect affordability.

list-item.p: 21. Carlson, T., and Y. Dierwechter. 2007. “Effects of Urban Growth Boundaries on Residential Development in Pierce County, Washington.” The Professional Geographer 59 (2): 209–20.

sec.p: The goal of this study is to assess the success of the 1995 implementation of an urban growth boundary (UGB) in Pierce County, Washington. The authors utilize the 1991–2002 residential building permit data and analyzed the spatial patterns of residential development both within and outside of the UGB before and after its implementation. This analysis suggests that the distribution of residential buildings did indeed become more contiguous after the UGB was established. Furthermore, a sharp decline in development outside of the UGB and a steady increase within it were found for the time period studied. This study not only provides a demonstration of a successful UGB management of residential development but also an easy replicable model for future UGB evaluations.

list-item.p: 22. Ding, C., G. J. Knaap, and L. D. Hopkins. 1999. “Managing Urban Growth with Urban Growth Boundaries: A Theoretical Analysis.” Journal of Urban Economics 46: 53–68.
Keywords: urban growth boundary, social welfare

sec.p: In this article, Ding et al. explain effects of urban growth boundaries (UGBs) on social welfare within the context of public goods and urban infrastructural investment. The models are inclusive of a number of factors such as aggregate urban land rents, agricultural rents, public service costs before and after UGB implementation, and the value of development costs before the UGB. According to the authors, the optimal UGB would be set at the current population level. UGBs are capable of increasing social welfare by constraining infrastructure consumption within a given period of time. The authors recommend that infrastructural enhancements should be coordinated with UGB expansions to insure the most efficient development patterns.

list-item.p: 23. Downs, A. 2002. “Have Housing Prices Risen Faster in Portland than Elsewhere?” Housing Policy Debate 13 (1): 7–31.
Keywords: Portland (Oregon), housing price, urban growth boundary

sec.p: Much debate has arisen over the effects of Portland Oregon’s urban growth boundary (UGB) on housing prices. To better understand these controversial dynamics, Downs poses the research questions of how fast housing prices have increased in Portland and how these increases have compared with other US metropolitan regions. Using sale price data on existing single-family homes from the National Association of Realtors and Freddie Mac, Downs performs multiple statistical analyses to assess Portland housing price increases, how they compared to housing price increases in other US cities, and the possible influence of the UGB. Findings show that prices escalated more quickly in the 1990s compared to the 1980s, the decade that immediately followed the UGB’s implementation. Housing prices in Portland have increased faster than comparable areas over 1990–1994, a period also characterized by strong job growth in Portland. An UGB dummy variable is used to test for potential growth boundary influence and is deemed statistically significant for the 1990 to 1994 time period. Downs concludes that while UGBs do not necessarily increase housing prices, they may exert their strongest influence on prices when combined with other determinants of housing demand, such as job growth.

list-item.p: 24. Jun, M. 2006. “The Effects of Portland’s Urban Growth Boundary on Housing Prices.” Journal of the American Planning Association 72 (2): 239–43.
Keywords: Portland (Oregon), housing price, urban growth boundary

sec.p: This brief article is intended to extend on the empirical body of literature on the effects of urban growth boundaries (UGB) on housing prices in Portland, Oregon. Jun states that his study differs from others in that it uses data at a small geographical level (block group instead of metropolitan area) and compares Portland with all other US metropolitan areas with populations of over a million persons for the years of 1990 and 2000. Jun’s analysis involves the regression of average home values on a UGB dummy variable as well as other relevant variables. Results demonstrate that the UGB dummy is insignificant and housing density is negatively related to housing prices. According to Jun’s concluding remarks, the price of housing is thus more likely to be affected by structural, accessibility and amenity factors, rather than by the boundary itself.

list-item.p: 25. Knaap, G. J., and L. D. Hopkins. 2001. “The Inventory Approach to Urban Growth Boundaries.” Journal of the American Planning Association 67 (3): 314–26.
Keywords: housing price, urban growth boundary

sec.p: This article presents urban growth boundaries (UGBs) as a double-edged sword that can actually perpetuate sprawl if not drawn stringently enough, yet cause undue housing price inflation if they are too stringent. Furthermore, Knaap and Hopkins point out that commonly used twenty-year timetables for periodic UGB expansion do not effectively address the inconstant nature of development trends and can consequently drive up land and housing prices. Thus, they argue that an inventory interpretation can provide better understanding of UGBs. This approach considers undeveloped land as a commodity that is unutilized until it comes into demand. An event-driven system of inventory allocation is advocated by the authors as opposed to the common time-driven system. Under the event-driven system, development needs would be closely monitored to determine the appropriate time for UGB expansion. The UGB then may be expanded when the supply of land reaches a designated critical level rather than simply when a certain interval of time has passed.

list-item.p: 26. Nelson, A. C., R. J. Burby, E. Feser, C. J. Dawkins, E. E. Malizia, and R. Quercia. 2004. “Urban Containment and Central-City Revitalization.” Journal of the American Planning Association 70 (4): 411–25.

sec.p: To test whether urban containment policies, such as urban growth boundaries, facilitate the revitalization of central cities, Nelson et al. compare real-estate development between urban areas with and without urban containment policies. National data on 144 US central studies are obtained from a prior study (Burby 2000) on central city revitalization, and urban containment policy information acquired through telephone surveys. Using the number of residential and nonresidential structures constructed between 1985 and 1995 as the dependent variable, Nelson et al. analyze these data through ordinary least squares regression, using urban containment policies established before 1985 as a key independent variable. Findings indicate forty more residential units per 1,000 persons were constructed in cities with urban containment policies than in cities without such policies. While nonresidential construction is also found to be higher in contained cities, effects of containment were found to be highest on residential development.

list-item.p: 27. Newburn, D. A., and P. Berck. 2006. “Modeling Suburban and Rural-Residential Development beyond the Urban Fringe.” Land Economics 82 (4): 481–99.
Keywords: California, zoning, urban growth boundary

sec.p: To answer the question of how the effects of land use policies differ between suburban and rural residential communities, Newburn and Berck utilize a spatially explicit model to examine residential development patterns in Sonoma County, California, which contains eight cities with urban growth boundaries (UGB). Using the Sonoma County General Plan and 1994–2001 land parcel data, this research focuses on the impacts of the provision of municipal water services and land use regulations on development density changes of land parcels that were undeveloped as of 1993. These land use changes were then compared with land use regulation policies through random-parameter logit estimation. Designation and provision of water and sewer services are found to be the most significant determinants of suburban development density. Zoning regulations are also found to diminish development densities, and large lot rural residential requirements appear to be perpetuators of low density sprawl. Therefore, the authors state that while UGBs may serve to monitor suburban sprawl, they may also fuel rural residential development and consequently perpetuate the depletion of green spaces.

list-item.p: 28. O’Toole, R. 2004. “A Portlander’s View of Smart Growth.” The Review of Austrian Economics 17 (2/3): 203–12.

sec.p: While planners in Portland, Oregon, have touted smart growth goals, such as affordable housing, open space preservation, and cleaner air, O’Toole challenges these claims and presents an argument that Portland’s planning policies have actually been a detriment to such aims. The article largely serves to examine the effects of land use planning policies within the Portland metropolitan area through an analysis of planning documents, reports, and opinion surveys. O’Toole sees smart growth planning as a source of diminishing homeownership opportunities, a reduction in open space, and growing congestion. In terms of housing, he states that the Portland housing market moved from being one of the nations’ most affordable to one of the least affordable during the 1990s. According to O’Toole, while two of the three Portland households could afford a median priced home prior to 1990, this number had decreased to less than a third by the time of this article’s publication. While some scholars and planners have attributed this trend to high rates of population growth, O’Toole states that other housing markets, such as Atlanta and Las Vegas, have maintained higher rates of affordable housing while experiencing similar if not greater rates of growth. Furthermore, efforts to increase housing densities are deemed as responsible for creating a disproportionate balance between multifamily and single-family housing that is not appropriately meeting the demands of the market.

list-item.p: 29. Phillips, J., and E. Goodstein. 2000. “Growth Management and Housing Prices: The Case of Portland Oregon.” Contemporary Economic Policy 18 (3): 334–44.
Keywords: affordability, Portland (Oregon), housing price, urban growth boundary

sec.p: While Portland, Oregon’s Urban Growth Boundary (UGB), has received praise for its accomplishments in restricting urban sprawl, it has also been charged with being responsible for creating an affordable housing crisis in the city. This study seeks to determine whether housing cost increases in Portland are more attributable to the UGB or to other trends that have resulted in escalating housing cost throughout the western region. Using the National Home Builder Association’s estimates of median housing prices for the years 1991 and 1996, the authors conduct a multiple regression analysis controlling for supply and demand effects to investigate how Portland housing prices fared compared to those in thirty-seven other major US cities. The results provide weak evidence that Portland’s UGB significantly increased hosing prices and state any increases attributable to the UGB are likely to be less than $10,000. In conclusion, the authors state that Portland’s UGB is an unlikely perpetuator of an affordability crisis in the city.

list-item.p: 30. Weitz, J., and T. Moore. 1998. “Development Inside Urban Growth Boundaries: Oregon’s Empirical Evidence of Contiguous Urban Form.” Journal of the American Planning Association 64 (4): 424–40.
Keywords: infill, Oregon, urban growth boundary

sec.p: With the purpose of discussing and evaluating the implications of urban growth boundary (UGB) policies in the state of Oregon, Weitz and Moore consider the findings of research conducted by Oregon Department of Land Conservation and Development (DLCD), review relevant literature on urban sprawl patterns, and discuss standards for evaluating growth patterns. The DLCD research consisted of three 1995 case studies which were developed to quantify the amount of land and the number of housing units of subareas with varying development patterns in Oregon communities with UGBs. Findings demonstrate that UGBs alone may not necessarily provide an adequate means for achieving the desired level of contiguous development. Considering these results as well as the reviewed literature, Weitz and Moore offer a framework of standards for further evaluation of development in Oregon. These standards encourage urban core development as well as urban infill redevelopment, deem other forms of development, such as urban strips as acceptable if contiguous or nearly contiguous to the urban core, and discourage urban cluster and other forms of dispersed development within UGBs.

list-item.p: 31. Woo, M., and J. Guldmann. 2011. “Impacts of Urban Containment Policies on the Spatial Structure of US Metropolitan Areas.” Urban Studies 48 (16): 3511–36.
Keywords: state-mandated urban growth boundary, local urban growth boundary, urban service area

sec.p: State-mandated urban growth boundary (UGB), local UGB, and urban service areas (USA) are examples for urban containment policies (UCPs). In terms of regulating land-use activities, state UGBs are the tightest policy and the USAs are the weakest. The article examines how these UCPs impact urban structure. One hundred and thirty-five metropolitan areas were selected as the focus, which the authors claimed to be representative of all the metropolitan areas in the US Descriptive statistics recommended that areas with UCPs tended to have higher level of housing price and more concentrated urban development. This is consistent of many other studies. In this research, urban structure is measured by the urban density gradient, which was derived using regression analysis based on 1990–2000 Traffic-Analysis-Zone level employment and population data. The authors innovatively incorporated these gradients in a structure equation model and used the existence of different UCPs to explain the change of urban structures. The authors concluded that state-mandated UGBs imposed a regional level control and were effective in containing both population and employment activities within central areas. Local UGBs only had impact on population activities, and USAs only had weak impacts on economic activities.

sec.title: 3. Impact Fees
sec.p:
32. Been, V. 2005. “Impact Fees and Housing Affordability.” Cityscape: A Journal of Policy Development and Research 8 (1): 139–85.
Keywords: affordability, impact fee, multifamily housing, housing price, segregation
This extensive review of literature provides a framework for understanding how impact fees affect housing markets, especially in terms of affordability and racial exclusion. The review presents an overview of impact fees, an analysis of their costs and benefits, and a detailed discussion of their effects on housing price and affordability. While impact fees are noted to internalize development costs, stabilize property taxes, and enable otherwise infeasible growth, some critics have charged that they drive up housing cost and may be intentionally used to exclude both low-income populations and minorities. While this review conveys a consensus that housing prices are generally increased by impact fees, Been states that such increases do not necessarily equate to decreases in affordability. This statement is justified with the argument that impact fees have the potential to lower property taxes, can include both incentives and mandates for affordable housing, and may enhance supply by allowing for greater growth to occur. For example, impact fees may promote more efficient land uses, such as multifamily housing, which can in turn create greater opportunities for affordable housing. According to Been, the findings of this body of literature should be carefully considered by decision makers to develop impact fee policies that neither exploit nor exclude consumers of housing.

list-item.p: 33. Burge, G., and K. Ihlanfeldt. 2006a. “The Effects of Impact Fees on Multifamily Housing Construction.” Journal of Regional Science 46 (1): 5–23.
Keywords: Florida, impact fee, multifamily housing

sec.p: According to Burge and Ihandfeldt, the implementation of impact fees can potentially help communities in overcoming the costs associated with multifamily housing development and allow for rezoning to higher density land uses. Their study examines data from thirty-three Florida metropolitan counties with multifamily development impact fee requirements over 1996–2003. Impact fees are broken down into two categories: water/sewer and non-water/sewer related. Results suggest that non-water/sewer impact fees increase the development of multifamily housing development in inner suburban areas, and water/sewer related fees result in less multifamily development throughout a metropolitan area. The authors state that impact fees will increase the development of multifamily housing only if the benefits of receiving approval for higher density projects outweigh the cost of the impact fee. Therefore, only non-water/sewer related fees provide such a benefit.

list-item.p: 34. Burge, G., and K. Ihlanfeldt. 2006b. “Impact Fees and Single-Family Home Construction.” Journal of Urban Economics 60: 284–306.
Keywords: Florida, impact fee, housing price, single-family housing

sec.p: This article explores the effect of impact fees on single-family housing construction in Florida through the estimation of separate construction and price models for small-, medium-, and large-sized homes in inner cities, inner and outer suburbs, and rural areas from 1993 to 2003. Impact fee implementation data for this panel were collected through contacting county planning and building offices, and impact fees are classified into two categories: those used to fund water/sewer infrastructure and those used to pay for non-water/sewer services (e.g., schools and roads). Interestingly, water/sewer fees are found to have statistically insignificant effects, and non-water/sewer impact fees are found to increase housing construction for all sizes of homes in inner suburban areas and medium-sized and large homes in outer suburbs. According to the price models, a $1.00 increase in impact fees is expected to increase the price of small, medium, and large housing by $.39, $.82, and $1.27, respectively, suggesting that developers are at least partially compensated for non-water/sewer impact fees in the form of higher housing demand due to the amenities funded by impact fees.

list-item.p: 35. Evans-Cowley, J. S., and L. L. Lawhon. 2003. “The Effects of Impact Fees on the Price of Housing and Land: A Literature Review.” Journal of Planning Literature 17: 351–59.
Keywords: affordability, impact fee, housing price

sec.p: In this literature review, Evans and Lawhon consider a number of prominent studies that theoretically and empirically address the issue of how the costs of impact fees are distributed to landowners, developers, and consumers of housing. This distribution of costs appears to be largely contingent on the elasticity of the market. In other words, if the market is competitive and offers an ample number of substitutes, impact fees are most likely to diminish the price of land. Thus, landowners will be the most likely to bear the costs of the fee. Conversely, if substitutable land for development is not available, the costs of impact fees are more likely to be capitalized into inflated housing prices. The authors also review empirical studies which chiefly utilize hedonic regression as their method of analysis.
