While a number of such studies have revealed that impact fees increase the price of both new and existing housing, they are critiqued for often failing to address the issues of how the quality of a community can change when impact fees are implemented. The authors also note that impact fees can be considered as regressive because their costs are felt more heavily by low and moderate income consumers of housing. However, affordable housing impact fee waivers as well as opportunities provided by infrastructural expansion are identified as potential mechanisms for addressing affordable housing needs.

list-item.p: 36. Evans-Cowley, J. S., F. A. Forgey, and R. C. Rutherford. 2005. “The Effect of Development Impact Fees on Land Values.” Growth and Change 36 (1): 100–112.
Keywords: impact fee, land value, Texas

sec.p: This brief study examined the effect of impact fees on land value, using forty-three Texas cities as a case study. The authors constructed a random effects model which estimated that for every $1,000 in impact fees, developed vacant lot values increased by 1.3 percent. However, for undeveloped lots, land values were estimated to decrease by .042 percent with every $1,000 increase in impact fees because the fee essentially made the land more expensive to develop. The authors interpreted this finding as that the cost of impact fees partially accrued to property owners. However, they stated that it was unclear whether developers paid for the remaining impact fee or whether they passed it onto homebuyers, making it difficult to discern the effect of impact fees on low- and moderate-income households.

list-item.p: 37. Heim, C. E. 2001. “Leapfrogging, Urban Sprawl, and Growth Management: Phoenix, 1950-2000.” American Journal of Economics and Sociology 60 (1): 245–83.
Keywords: affordability, growth management, impact fee, infill, Phoenix (Arizona)

sec.p: This case study of Phoenix, Arizona, provides a context for understanding the development of sprawl throughout the city in the last half of the twentieth century and the negative impacts, such as scattered tracts of undeveloped urban land (leapfrogging). The two main mechanisms for sprawl control are the implementation of impact fees in 1987 and the infill housing program of 1995. Designed to assist in paying for infrastructure and discouraging leapfrogging, impact fees, ranging from $2,112 to $9,471, have been charged for residential developments in parts of the metropolitan area with strong infrastructural demands. Heim notes that this program has been successful in alleviating the fiscal strains of infrastructure development, but housing affordability challenges may be present if construction of multifamily housing is delayed or if cost burdens are shifted toward homeowners. With the goals of promoting quality housing and homeownership in the city, the infill housing program offers the incentives of waived development fees and expedited development review processes. While this program has assisted in initiating almost 17,000 projects permits by 2000, Heim states that the housing program did not strongly encourage high density development.

list-item.p: 38. Ihlanfeldt, K. R., and T. M. Shaughnessy. 2004. “An Empirical Investigation of the Effects of Impact Fees on Housing and Land Markets.” Regional Science and Urban Economics 34: 639–61.
Keywords: Florida, impact fee, single-family housing, housing price

sec.p: In this article, Ihlandfldt and Shaughnessy estimate the effect of impact fees on single-family home and undeveloped land in Dade County, Florida. Monthly indices of price are constructed with Dade County appraisal data for the years of 1985–2000 and then a model is estimated to explain changes in metropolitan prices over time. Results show that a $1.00 increase in impact fees raises the average existing home price by $1.67. Regression estimates also suggest that property tax savings are roughly in line with housing price increases. Conversely, land values are demonstrated to fall by approximately the value of the impact fee. Thus, while housing developers may be fully compensated for the cost of impact fees, regulatory delays and other uncertainties appear to lower their willingness to pay for vacant land.

list-item.p: 39. Mathur, S. 2007. “Do Impact Fees Raise the Price of Existing Housing?” Housing Policy Debate 18 (4): 635–59.

sec.p: Using a hedonic analysis framework, Mathur measured the effect of impact fees on the price of existing single-family housing in King County, Washington. He hypothesized that impact fees would increase housing price, and such impacts would vary according to housing quality. Using tax assessment records for housing sales occurring between 1991 and 2000, Mathur constructed three separate hedonic models to all housing sales, low-quality homes, and high-quality homes, respectively. Housing quality was determined based on the classification by the county assessor. For all housing sales, Mathur found a statistically significant increase of $0.53 to $1.12 for every $1.00 increase in impact fees depending on the quality of homes. For high-quality homes, the price of a home increased by $0.59–$1.47 for every dollar increase in impact fees. However, in the model for low-quality homes, impact fees were found to have an insignificant effect. Mathur concluded that while impact fees increased housing costs, and worsened affordability for moderate- to high-income households. Nevertheless, it did not thwart affordability for low- and moderate-income households.

list-item.p: 40. Mathur, S., P. Waddell, and H. Blanco. 2004. “The Effect of Impact Fees on the Price of New Single-Family Housing.” Urban Studies 41 (7): 1303–12.
Keywords: impact fee, housing price, low-quality housing, high-quality housing

sec.p: Mathur et al. examined the effects of impact fees on the 1991–2000 sale prices of newly constructed single-family homes in King County, Washington. Data from county tax assessment records for all new housing sales were used in a hedonic model. The results indicated that every $1.00 increase in impact fees resulted in a $1.66 increase in the price of the home. Two additional models were also constructed to test whether impact fees had differentiated effects on housing units of different levels of quality. For low-quality housing model, positive, but insignificant results were found. The authors stated that this submarket may be characterized by greater price elasticity in which consumers and developers may shift to the multifamily housing market. High-quality housing bore stronger price increases with a $1.00 increase in impact fees resulting in a $3.58 increase in the sale price of the home, demonstrating that consumers actually pay more than the cost of the impact fee. The authors suggested that extended processing time and other out of pocket costs associated with impact fees may have contributed to this strong increase or that the benefits provided by the impact fees were actually higher than the amount of fees.

list-item.p: 41. Mayer, C. J., and C. T. Somerville. 2000. “Land Use Regulation and New Construction.” Regional Science and Urban Economics 30: 639–62.
Keywords: impact fee, land use regulation, single-family housing

sec.p: According to Mayer and Somerville, previous work on land use regulation and housing has focused almost exclusively on housing price effects. This study, however, investigates how regulations affect housing supply (i.e., residential construction) and uses quarterly data on the number of new single-family housing permits issued over 1985–1996 in forty-four metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs), along with land use regulation information obtained from a 1991 survey of local planners. Regulations are considered in terms of two classes, those that charge developers with an explicit monetary fee (such as an impact fee) and regulations that impose long delays to development. Land use regulations are also found to reduce the ability of developers to respond to supply shocks. New residential construction as measured by the mean number of construction starts for housing units are shown to be up to 45 percent lower in the MSAs that demonstrated the most stringent growth regulation than in MSAs without stringent regulation. Conversely, impact fees are shown to have minimally significant effects on housing starts.

list-item.p: 42. Skidmore, M., and M. Peddle. 1998. “Do Development Impact Fees Reduce the Rate of Residential Development?” Growth and Change 29: 383–400.

sec.p: In this study, impact fees are considered for their effects on residential development patterns. Impact fees imply not only increased development costs but also potential reductions in property tax. Taking both factors into consideration, Skidmore and Peddle state that impact fee effects are theoretically ambiguous and thus propose an investigation of how impact fees affect residential markets. DuPage County, Illinois, is selected as a case study because of the variation in impact fee policies throughout its municipalities and its fast population growth in the state over 1977–1992. The authors demonstrate that impact fees lead to a 25 percent reduction in development rates, when taking into consideration a 4 percent increase due to property tax reductions. Skidmore and Peddle conclude that impact fees represent a means not only to redistributing infrastructural costs but also to slowing residential growth to more efficient levels.

sec.title: 4. New Urbanism
sec.p:
43. Bohl, C. C. 2000. “New Urbanism and the City: Potential Applications and Implications for Distressed Inner-City Neighborhoods.” Housing Policy Debate 11 (4): 761–801.
Keywords: affordability, HOPE VI, new urbanism, public housing, Seaside (Florida)
This article demonstrates the dynamic relationship between New Urbanism and other sectors of the planning field including sustainable development, historic preservation, smart growth, and growth management. Examples from the Housing and Urban Development (HUD), such as Housing Opportunities for People Everywhere (HOPE VI), are used to exemplify the influence of New Urbanism in housing policy. While some new urbanist projects, such as Seaside, Florida, cast New Urbanism as an unaffordable strategy, HOPE VI projects have shown how new urbanist design principles can be used to develop low-income housing that is both appealing and well integrated into traditional urban communities. While the private sector has been largely unwilling and/or unable to produce low-income housing units, the authors provide examples of projects from various US cities that demonstrate a diversity of arrangements between the public and private sectors. To further enhance affordable housing communities, through the principles of New Urbanism, the authors recommend such government actions as inclusionary zoning, fair-share housing policies, density bonuses, and construction subsidies.

list-item.p: 44. Forsyth, A. 2002. “Planning Lessons from Three U.S. New Towns of the 1960s and 1970s: Irvine, Columbia, and The Woodlands.” Journal of the American Planning Association 68 (4): 387–415.
Keywords: affordability, Columbia (Maryland), equity, Irvine (California), new urbanism, smart growth, The Woodlands (Texas)

sec.p: Irvine, Columbia, and the Woodlands were new towns of the 1960s and 1970s that have often been considered as models for sprawl reduction and smart growth planning. To evaluate this claim, Forsyth offers case studies of each of these communities with explicit emphasis on their successes in meeting smart growth goals including the provision of diverse and affordable housing stocks. Data for these case studies are obtained from a number of sources, including interviews, census data, community archives, and GIS mapping, and so on. Because each of these communities grew to be full-scale cities of 100,000 to over 400,000 persons, Forsyth states they have been forced to tackle affordable housing issues avoided by other residential developments of their time. These towns are said to represent innovative approaches to housing with Irvine pioneering efforts to develop housing for diversified household types and Columbia being a leader in the racial integration. Each new town includes government-sponsored affordable housing which accounts for 5–6 percent of their housing stocks. According to Forsyth, the design quality of this affordable housing is great and virtually indistinguishable from more expensive housing within these communities. However, these towns have experienced difficulty in developing a private affordable housing market. While Forsyth concludes that Columbia, Irvine, and the Woodlands appear to be in line with many goals of smart growth and New Urbanism, she remains uncertain about their success in enhancing social equity.

list-item.p: 45. Grant, J. L. 2007. “Two Sides of a Coin? New Urbanism and Gated Communities.” Housing Policy Debate 18 (3): 481–501.

sec.p: In this study of gated communities and New Urbanist developments in Canada, Grant compared similarities and differences between these two planning paradigms based on document and plan analysis, field research, and personal interviews. These two types of development have different underlying philosophies. However, Grant found them to be very similar in terms of design, site location, safety concern, community governance, and demographics. Both types of communities were found to be principally marketed to upscale households and were socially homogenous. While New Urbanism embraced diversity in theory, Grant claimed that in practice these developments exhibit less diversity than conventional suburbs. Instead, New Urbanist developments primarily provided housing for the privileged classes, demonstrating New Urbanism’s limited viability in promoting affordable housing opportunities.

list-item.p: 46. Hanlon, J. 2010. “Success by Design: HOPE VI, New Urbanism, and the Neoliberal Transformation of Public Housing in the United States.” Environment and Planning A 42: 80–98.
Keywords: new urbanism, HOPE VI, The Park DuValle Project

sec.p: The Park DuValle Housing Project in Louisville, KY, was responsible for replacing the city’s Cotter Homes and Lang Homes public housing projects with mixed income, New Urbanist communities. In this case study of Park DuValle, Hanlon used media reports, sites studies and assessments, housing authority documents, and census data to understand the financing of the development and assessed its socioeconomic impact. While Park DuValle has been considered a highly successful example of HOPE VI revitalization in terms of public–private partnership formation, falling poverty rates, and attracting higher-income residents, Hanlon pointed out a number of more troubling trends. In terms of finance, with private sector funding only account for 36.6 percent, federal, state, and local dollars were still the main financial sources. Further, the project essentially replaced 1,116 public housing units with 363 onsite units and 140 offsite units, creating substantial concerns about displacement of very low-income households. Many of these displaced residents were found to have been moved to other public housing units in neighborhoods with high rates of poverty and unemployment, suggesting that these residents were merely relocated from one highly distressed neighborhood to another. Housing improvements for former Cotter-Lang residents were also found to be limited, in terms of rent and safety in their new neighborhoods.

list-item.p: 47. Johnson, J. S., and E. Talen. 2008. “Affordable Housing in New Urbanist Communities: A Survey of Developers.” Housing Policy Debate 19 (4): 583–613.

sec.p: This article is quite descriptive, presenting how and to what extent affordability is considered in New Urbanism based on a valuable survey of new urbanist developers across the nation. A majority of the respondents (about 55.6 percent) indicated that affordable housing was concluded in their projects for various reasons, for instance, meeting community demand, receiving financial assistance, and local government requirement. Federal, state, and local governments all played important roles, by adopting various programs to provide financial incentives to developers, subsidies to home buyers or renters, and infrastructure support for a community. However, 62.7 percent of the respondents stated that their development was located at an exurban (42.2 percent) or a suburban (20.5 percent) site. Obviously, these projects were not targeted at low-income population. The other 44.4 percent of respondents did not consider affordability, most often because of profit reason. They thought low-income population was an “inappropriate mix” and their properties were too expensive for this population. It is worthwhile to point out that the authors admit that with the survey cover letter stating affordability as the purpose of their study, the respondents (with response rate 38 percent) could be self-selective. Developers who did not consider affordability tend not respond. This implies that affordable housing may be less considered in practice than as described in the article.

list-item.p: 48. Matthews, J. W., and G. K. Turnbull. 2007. “Neighborhood Street Layout and Property Value: The Interaction of Accessibility and Land Use Mix.” Journal of Real Estate Finance Economics 35: 111–41.
Keywords: new urbanism, property value, Washington

sec.p: Noting that other studies have identified positive relationships between New Urbanism and property values, Matthews and Turnbull pose the question of what elements of New Urbanism are most influential and pay particular attention to the influence from street layout and design. The study focuses on two communities within King County, Washington, one with a more traditional urban gridiron street layout and another exemplifying conventional curvilinear suburban street design. The study utilizes a hedonic model with housing and neighborhood data from county tax assessment records. GIS techniques are used to develop variables for land use mixes, population densities, and street distances. Space syntax and an alternative ratio method are used to measure neighborhood layout and street connectivity. Results suggest that proximity to retail tends to have a positive and significant impact on property values in pedestrian-oriented communities, but an insignificant relationship in more automobile reliant communities. Neighborhood layout and design are also shown to have an effect that is both sensitive to measurement and covaries with other relevant variables. The authors conclude that while the appeal of New Urbanism design may not be universal, it does satisfy the needs of significant subsets of the population.

list-item.p: 49. Song, Y., and G. Knaap. 2003. “New Urbanism and Housing Values: A Disaggregate Assessment.” Journal of Urban Economics 54: 218–38.
Keywords: new urbanism, Oregon, property value

sec.p: Song and Knaap conduct this study to determine whether the design features of New Urbanism have an effect on property values. The study operationalizes the new urbanist design features of street design, density, land use mix, transportation accessibility, and walkability as key independent variables. Focused on the Washington County portion of Portland Oregon, data are derived from tax assessment records, the US Census, and the Portland Metro’s regional land use system to capture the 48,070 transactions conducted between 1990 and 2000. A hedonic price model is utilized to identify both the isolated and combined housing value effects of the variables. Findings indicate that while some components, such as access to light rail, have positive effects on home values, others, including high residential density and proximity to commercial land uses can lessen property value. To understand the combined effect of these results, Song and Knaap use the model to compute the predicted value of a standardized house in a new urbanist neighborhood, and compare it to that of a more traditionally designed neighborhood. The home in the new urbanist neighborhood is found to command a 15.5 percent price premium, indicating that the virtues of New Urbanism are deemed to outweigh its detractions.

list-item.p: 50. Song, Y., and G. Knapp. 2004. “Measuring the Effects of Mixed Land Uses on Housing Values.” Regional Science and Urban Economics 34: 663–80.
Keywords: Oregon, smart growth, property value

sec.p: Considering mixed land uses as an emphasized component of smart growth, Song and Knaap utilize GIS to determine the effects of mixed land uses on residential property values in Washington County, Oregon. The study uses factors, such as accessibility, neighborhood land use proportions, and balance of housing to jobs, to assess whether mixed land uses led to lower or higher property values. According to their findings, prices tended to increase with better proximity to commercial centers and public parks, decrease with proximity to multifamily housing, and keep stable with proximity to industrial and other institutional land uses. Song and Knaap also report that prices increase in neighborhoods with similar land use activities. In conclusion, the authors state that simply mixing land uses is not sufficient for achieving real smart growth.

list-item.p: 51. Talen, E. 2002. “The Social Goals of New Urbanism.” Housing Policy Debate 13(1): 165-88.

sec.p: Talen defines the social goals as community engagement, social equity, and the common good, and develops a methodology for evaluating the social significance of New Urbanism. While high-income new urbanist communities, such as Celebration, Florida, and Kentlands, Maryland, have not been deemed as being socially equitable, Talen moves beyond these examples and considers the social potential of the New Urbanism movement as a whole. To do this, Talen evaluates the twenty-seven principles of the Chapter of New Urbanism. While none of these principles are found to be explicitly linked to community goals, eight were found to be related to goals of social equity, and nineteen were found to be related to achieving a common good. Two goals pertaining to housing fell within the social equity category: promoting affordable housing through urban infill development and population diversity through integrating multiple housing types within neighborhoods. According to Talen, mixing housing types serves as one of the only ways that planners can address the issues of concentrated poverty and enhance the opportunity for resources to be distributed in a geographically equitable manner.

list-item.p: 52. Talen, E. 2008. “New Urbanism, Social Equity, and the Challenge of Post-Katrina Rebuilding in Mississippi.” Journal of Planning Education and Research 27: 277–93.
Keywords: equity, new urbanism, Mississippi Gulf Coast rebuilding plans

sec.p: The rebuilding plans in the Mississippi Gulf Coast after the Hurricane Katrina followed the New Urbanism model. These activities have generated a new round of discussions about how to promote social equity. In this article, Talen interpreted social equality as good community engagement, appropriate socioeconomic diversity, and equal access to activities at the neighborhood level. She assessed whether the rebuilding activities have promoted social equality. Two innovative practices, Katrina cottage and Smartcode, were viewed as successful tools in promoting affordability. A Katrina cottage is a small and easily constructed housing unit. A smartcode allows for mixed activities and house types in a zone and is a replacement of a traditional zoning. Talen, nevertheless, also pointed out that many urban urbanism practices in the public realm were against the goal of promoting social equity. For instance, major transportation projects and plans paid little attention to walkability. Municipalities failed to adopt an appropriate neighborhood organization structure, which Talen thought is critical for maintain social equality. A section is specifically devoted in discussing how to promote affordability. It is argued that both policy and design are critical. The focus on architecture and design is often observed in practices. However, very little attention is put on policy side. In Mississippi, local governments did not advocate such political tools as linkage fees, profit sharing, and inclusionary zoning. Talen called for efforts to fill the gap between policy and design.

list-item.p: 53. Talen, E. 2010. “Affordability in New Urbanist Development: Principle, Practice, and Strategy.” Journal of Urban Affairs 32 (4): 489–510.

sec.p: Social mixing is one important principle in urban urbanism development to promote diversity and to fight urban poverty. At the same time, new urbanists attempt to maintain housing affordability by reducing the size and therefore directly lowering property cost. Further, it is claimed that walkability reduces living costs (related to transportation) and makes houses more affordable. In this article, Talen evaluated whether new urbanism is affordable in a market economy. She conducted a survey of housing prices in 234 New Urbanism neighborhoods (excluding governmental projects), with a response rate of 65.0 percent. The lowest unit price for each neighborhood was compared with the corresponding local salary level. Results indicate that only 15 percent of the neighborhoods have at least one house that is affordable for a moderate income person, 10 percent have such a unit for teacher with median salary, and 1 percent for a cook. Talen further examined levels of affordability based on home sales information by region. New Urbanism neighborhoods in the Midwest region tended to have higher level of affordability. Talen pointed out that strategies need to consider local market factors and regulatory background. In areas with low land value and low affordability requirement in local policy, the focus should be on design. In areas with high land value and low affordability regulation, planners need to consider both design elements and cost-effective ways. Planners may also play the role as coordinators to promote walkability between neighborhoods. For areas with high land value and high level of regulation, government policy will be an effective tool.

list-item.p: 54. Tu, C. C., and M. J. Eppli. 1999. “Valuing New Urbanism: The Case of Kentlands.” Real Estate Economics 27 (3): 425–51.
Keywords: Kentlands (Maryland), new urbanism, housing price

sec.p: In this empirical study of the new urbanist community of Kentlands, Maryland, Tu and Eppli consider the desirability of New Urbanism and the willingness of housing consumers to pay for its benefits. The authors use multiple hedonic models to determine whether Kentlands housing prices are different in comparison to similar housing units located in more traditionally planned communities within the same county. Housing data from the Maryland State Department of Assessment and Taxation were acquired for 2,061 transactions occurring between 1994 and 1996, 13 percent of which were for housing units located in Kentlands. Location within Kentlands was used to operationalize New Urbanism as the key independent variable with twenty-eight other independent variables also used to control for housing characteristics. Analysis of the model indicates that housing in the Kentlands commanded premiums of approximately 12 percent or $25,000 more than homes in other nearby communities. An analysis of interaction effects demonstrates that higher prices in the Kentlands are likely attributable to New Urbanism. While the authors state that this study demonstrates increased housing values may be associated with New Urbanism, they also warn that results are not necessarily generalizable because the study only focuses on a single community.

sec.title: 5. Transit-oriented Development
sec.p:
55. Bowes, D. R., and K. R. Ihlanfeldt. 2001. “Identifying the Impacts of Rail Transit Stations on Residential Property Values.” Journal of Urban Economics 50: 1–25.
Keywords: Atlanta (Georgia), equity, rail transit, property value
This study focuses on the impacts of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority’s (MARTA) rail stations on owner-occupied single-family properties. Relevant factors (e.g., retail development, crime rates, accessibility, noise, and pollution) are incorporated into three statistical models to provide a better understanding of their relationship and collective effect upon residential property values. Home sale prices are gathered using 1991–1994 county tax assessment records, and information on retail activity and crime rates are obtained from marketing research of the Atlanta Regional Commission and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Results convey that while properties located within a quarter mile of a station are found to sell for 19 percent less than those located further away, properties located between 1 and 3 miles of a station are found to have higher values than those further away from transit stations. Cumulative results suggest variations related to income levels, and distance from both stations and downtown. The largest positive effects are found in high income neighborhoods located between a quarter mile and 3 miles of a station, and negative effects beyond the quarter mile mark were generally restricted to low income communities. Negative crime effects are seen to be contained mostly in downtown areas.

list-item.p: 56. Cervero, R., and M. Duncan. 2002. “Benefits of Proximity to Rail on Housing Markets: Experiences in Santa Clara County.” Journal of Public Transportation 5 (1): 1–17.
Keywords: affordability, California, rail transit, transit oriented development, property value

sec.p: Santa Clara County, California, an area confronted with traffic congestion and housing affordability problems, has made extensive efforts to promote transit-oriented development (TOD) as a strategy for coping with these issues. This analysis of the real-estate capitalization effects of light rail and commuter rail proximity is intended to demonstrate the economic benefits of these efforts. The study utilizes a hedonic price model with the per square foot value of land designated as the dependent variable. Sale prices for the year 1999 are attainted through the real-estate transaction database. Metroscan and GIS are utilized to determine proximity to transit systems, including light and commuter rail systems as well as freeways. While benefits are associated with proximity to all forms of transit, the greatest are found in rail transit, especially commuter rail. Furthermore, while a disamenity effect is associated with being located too close to freeways, no such effect found is found for rail transit. The study also finds that neighborhood characteristics of TODs, such as mixed land uses and job-resident balance, added value to residential parcels. In conclusion, Cervero and Duncan note that municipalities can take advantage of these economic benefits through property taxes and the joint development of properties within close proximity to transit.

list-item.p: 57. Debrezion, G., E. Pels, and P. Rietveld. 2007. “The Impact of Railway Stations on Residential and Commercial Property Value: A Meta-Analysis.” Journal of Real Estate Finance Economics 35: 161–80.

sec.p: Recognizing the diversity of methodologies, foci, and results of research pertaining to the connection between property value and proximity to railway stations, Debrezion et al. utilize meta-analytic methods to explain the variation in existing studies and further explore this relationship. After reviewing previous studies, the authors propose a hedonic pricing method, known as the meta-regression model, to synthesize fifty-seven preexisting studies. The dependent variable of the effect size of railway stations on property values is standardized into the percentage change of property value or rent for every 250 meters of distance between a property and a railway station as well as the general effect of being located within a quarter mile of a station. Independent variables include whether a property is residential or commercial, accessibility to other transportation modes, and type of railway transit. Findings indicate a price increase of approximately 4.2 percent for the average residence within a quarter mile of a train station, and prices also increase by 2.4 percent for every 250 meters they are closer to a station. Commuter rail is also shown to have a stronger impact than other railway types. The authors also find accessibility to other modes of transit, such as highways, to lower impacts of studies and warn that isolating studies to only the effects of rail may lead to omitted variable bias.

list-item.p: 58. Hess, D. B. and T. M. Almeida. 2007. “Impact of Proximity to Light Rail Rapid Transit on Station-Area Property Values in Buffalo, New York.” Urban Studies 44 (5/6): 1041–68.
Keywords: affordability, Buffalo (New York), rail transit, property value

sec.p: This article explores the effects of a twenty-year-old light rail system on residential property values in Buffalo, New York. The study is unique in that it looks at the effects of rail transit in the context of a declining Rustbelt city, opposed to previous studies which tend to focus on growing Sunbelt cities, such as Dallas or Portland. In order to capture the value of all residential properties, the authors paired the 2002 Buffalo property tax assessment database with GIS maps to identify properties located within a half mile of transit stations. Utilizing a hedonic regression model, the authors find that the expected value of properties located within a half of a mile of transit stations increases $.99 to $2.31 per foot of distance to the station, indicating property value increases of $990 to $2,310 for properties located within 1,000 feet of light rail transit stations. While findings suggest that proximity to light rail does increase property value in Buffalo, these increases are not as great as those that have been found in growing urban areas. The authors perceive this finding as a potential opportunity for the city of Buffalo to promote transit friendly and affordable housing.

list-item.p: 59. Kahn, M. E. 2007. “Gentrification Trends in New Transit-Oriented Communities: Evidence from 14 Cities that Expanded and Built Rail Transit Systems.” Real Estate Economics 35 (2): 155–82.
Keywords: gentrification, rail transit, transit oriented development

sec.p: Kahn’s analysis of the effects of transit enhancements is inclusive of fourteen major US cities that either built or expanded railway transit systems between the years of 1970 and 2000. This study is said to be unique from others because it includes such a large area and also identifies the occurrence of gentrification as the dependent variable. Analysis is performed through a linear probability model with data obtained from a number of sources including the Urban Institute and the National Transportation Atlas. Gentrification is defined and operationalized by both changes in home prices and the demographic share of college graduates. Kahn also distinguishes between the effects of “park and ride” stations and “walk and ride” stations. The authors find that results fluctuate among the various cities studied. However, the analysis indicates a pattern of communities that received “walk and ride” stations experiencing increases in both housing prices and shares of college graduates, while those with “park and ride” stations experienced decreases in these factors. Thus, results indicate that pedestrian oriented stations may serve as magnets for gentrification, while automobile-oriented stations may actually serve to attract poverty.

list-item.p: 60. Knaap, G. J., C. Ding, and L. D. Hopkins. 2001. “Do Plans Matter? The Effects of Light Rail Plans on Land Values in Station Areas.” Journal of Planning Education and Research 21: 32–39.
Keywords: Oregon, rail transit, property value

sec.p: In this study, Knaap et al. explore the effects of planned light rail transit on both property values and development patterns in Washington County, Oregon. The light rail system, connecting downtown Portland to other cities within the metropolitan area, was formally announced in 1993 and opened in 1998. To understand the effects of this transit advancement and the planning process which framed its implementation, Knaap et al. consider how land values changed between the announcement of the transit line’s construction and its completion. A hedonic regression model is constructed, using data pertaining to the transactions of all vacant land parcels within a mile of future rail stations from January 1992 to August 1996. Results indicate that while land values along the corridor were not statistically higher than outside parcels in 1992 or 1993, parcels within a half mile of the proposed stations were 71 percent higher in 1994 and 21 percent higher in 1995. Parcels within a mile of the proposed stations were 10 percent higher in 1994 and 9 percent higher in 1995. According to Knaap et al., these findings suggest that information about light rail plans are observed by developers and capitalized into land values, and the model supports planning’s ability to alter land development patterns.

list-item.p: 61. Lund, H. 2006. “Reasons for Living in a Transit Oriented-Development, and Associated Transit Use.” Journal of the American Planning Association 72 (3): 357–66.
Keywords: affordability, Los Angeles (California), San Diego (California), San Francisco (California), housing price, segregation, transit oriented development

sec.p: Lund’s study uses survey data of Californians living in transit oriented developments (TODs) to better understand who moves to TODs as well as their motivations. Data are obtained from surveys of 605 recent residents of TODs within California’s largest metropolitan areas (Los Angles, San Diego, and San Francisco Bay) during 2003 and 2004. Results indicate that residents in these communities were less likely to be Hispanic and low-income and more likely to be employed as professionals or office workers in comparison to the residents of their surrounding cities. In addition to demographic questions, the survey asked respondents to indicate their top three reasons for moving into a TOD. The three most highly ranked motivations include quality/type of housing, housing costs, and quality of neighborhoods. Binary logistic regression is employed to determine the probability of a respondent indicating certain preferences. Cost of housing was deemed to be most important to lower-income households and also ranked of higher significance of those living in the Los Angles and Bay areas. Lund suggests that these preferences indicate that TODs can assist in meeting a wide range of needs extending beyond transit.

list-item.p: 62. McMillen, D. P., and J. McDonald. 2004. “Reaction of House Prices to a New Rapid Transit Line: Chicago’s Midway Line, 1983-1999.” Real Estate Economics 32 (3): 463–86.
Keywords: Chicago, housing price, rail transit

sec.p: McMillen and McDonald’s study focuses on the price effects of transit enhancements in Chicago, Illinois. In order to determine both anticipated and realized benefits of the railway opening, the authors utilize data from tax records that are inclusive of 17,034 single-family transactions occurring within 1.5 miles of the rail line from the years of 1983 to 1999. Utilizing GIS to identify proximity to the line, hedonic regression and sales estimation methods are used to determine the price effects of distance to stations in twelve different communities along the rail line. While price changes varied among different station areas, the authors find that the overall rate of increase in the study areas were 6.89 percent higher than other nearby homes for the years of 1986 and 1999. Furthermore, the rate of increase was 4.02 percent higher for the 1986 to 1990 time period, indicating that anticipated benefits have been capitalized into housing prices several years prior to the railway’s opening. These differences amount to an estimated premium of approximately $6,000 per home, suggesting a heightened willingness to pay for proximity to light rail transit systems.

list-item.p: 63. Renne, J. L. 2005. “Transit Oriented Development: Measuring Benefits, Analyzing Trends, and Evaluating Policy.” PhD diss. Rutgers: The State University of New Jersey.
Keywords: affordability, California, displacement, Florida, Georgia, Maryland, New Jersey, Oregon, transit oriented development

sec.p: Renne’s dissertation research takes a nationwide approach in exploring the effects of TODs on commuting trends and demographic patterns, as well as how private land market and public policy influence housing affordability in TODs. To answer these research questions, both quantitative and qualitative methods are employed. Time-series analysis of 1970, 1980, 1990, and 2000 US Census Data is used to compare and contrast travel trends, automobile ownership, and demographic distributions of 103 TODs compared to their respective metropolitan areas. Overall, nonwhite and foreign born populations within the TODs are found to be similar to that of the surrounding metropolitan areas. However, some variations are demonstrated, such as significantly higher numbers of nonwhites living in California TODs and less living in Miami TODs. TODs are also found to have higher rates of poverty and higher percentages of renters than other areas of their respective metropolitan areas. While Renne finds no conclusive evidence of displacement, he warns that development trends and consumer demands may lead to future trends of gentrification. To further explore these issues, case studies of smart growth and transit oriented development policies in the states of California, New Jersey, Maryland, Florida, and Oregon are presented. While these states exemplify substantial achievement in addressing smart growth goals, Renne notes that California has been the only state to strongly address affordable housing, and governmental policies are identified as a necessary component for achieving goals of affordable housing and compact development.

list-item.p: 64. Renne, J. L. 2008. “Smart Growth and Transit-Oriented Development at the State Level: Lessons from California, New Jersey, and Western Australia.” Journal of Public Transportation 11 (3): 77–108.
Keywords: transit-oriented development, California, New Jersey, Western Australia, political context

sec.p: State governments play critical role in TOD development, because they often define the overall political tone and provide financial support. In California, with strong grass-root support for smart growth, the state has initiated several programs to provide grant and technical support to encourage mixed-use and TOD. Further, the state replaced the old tax credit distribution system (a random lottery system) with a new point-based one that considers various amenities, including distance to a public transit system. This increased accessibility of affordable homes. New Jersey has a comprehensive agenda for promoting TOD, covering most important elements in planning, such as affordable housing, open space preservation, brownfield development, zoning, and transportation. The State government is directly involved in TOD projects through the designation of nineteen transit villages that are directly supervised by the state government. In Australian political system, the state government has more power. Western Australia adopted the Network City Action Plan, which links local TODs to regional growth to promote a city network with interconnected TODs. The TOD committee was formed in 2004 as a cross-agency group involving various state and local offices, and directly worked with developers to expedite TOD programs. Based on the experience of these three states, Renne recommended ten strategies to promote TOD, covering such issues as intrastate and intergovernmental cooperation, participation from the transportation and public housing sectors, well-prepared short- and long-term plans, independent committee to provide supervision.

sec.title: 6. Urban Infill/Revitalization
sec.p:
65. Boston, T. D. 2005. “The Effects of Revitalization on Public Housing Residents: A Case Study of the Atlanta Housing Authority.” Journal of the American Planning Association 71 (4): 393–407.
Keywords: Atlanta (Georgia), displacement, HOPE VI, new urbanism, public housing, revitalization
The HOPE VI program has sought to reform public housing by revitalizing urban public housing sites through new urbanist design including the implementation of mixed-income housing. In this study of Atlanta, Boston explores the effects of these revitalization efforts on the recipients of public housing. The study employs a quasi-experimental design which compares residents of three public housing communities that underwent revitalization projects in the late 1990s and early 2000s to three that were not. The Atlanta Housing Authority’s administrative data are used to provide data from 1995 to 2001 on 1,235 households in revitalized public housing projects and 1,483 households living in nonrevitalized public housing. While previous studies have claimed that mixed-income revitalization will lead to higher levels of displacement from public housing, Boston finds that attrition rates were actually 4 percent lower for households in the revitalized communities compared to those that were not revitalized. Further logistic regression analysis found no significant differences in housing assistance attrition through revitalized and unrevitalized areas. Boston finds that recipients using housing vouchers as well as those living in revitalized projects have gained greater housing choice, and demonstrated substantially higher rates of employment (45 percent and 50.3 percent, respectively), compared to those who relocated to conventional public housing (19.8 percent). Boston concludes that properly administered revitalization and relocation programs, such as HOPE VI projects, have the potential to create better housing outcomes for public housing recipients.

list-item.p: 66. Farris, J. T. 2001. “The Barriers to Using Urban Infill Development to Achieve Smart Growth.” Housing Policy Debate 12 (1): 1–29.
Keywords: displacement, gentrification, infill, smart growth

sec.p: In this article, Farris outlines those barriers believed to prevent a greater volume of urban infill redevelopment. The price of developing a square foot of land on a previously undeveloped suburban site is estimated to be approximately $.25 to $4.00, based on his seventeen-year experience as a developer in St. Louis. Conversely, the redevelopment of a square foot of urban land is estimated to cost $15.00 per square foot if all relevant fees and requirements are considered. Farris’s extensive list of barriers also includes the challenges of marketing urban lifestyles, negative externalities, eminent domain issues, a complex system of red tape, infrastructure replacement, historic preservation interests, the requirements of incoming businesses, and the threat of gentrification and displacement. Because of these extensive costs, Farris feels public subsidies are likely to be required to encourage urban infill redevelopment projects. Farris recommends that proponents of smart growth direct the focus of their energies to a more realistic task of creating more efficient and denser developments on the urban periphery rather than large scale redevelopment of existing urban locations.

list-item.p: 67. Lee, S., and N. G. Leigh. 2005. “The Role of Inner Ring Suburbs in Metropolitan Smart Growth Strategies.” Journal of Planning Literature 19: 330–46.
Keywords: affordability, infill, revitalization, smart growth

sec.p: This article explores the challenges and opportunities presented to smart growth by inner ring suburbs, which have experienced population and income declines in recent decades. According to Lee and Leigh, because inner ring suburbs have the advantage of proximity to both the metropolitan center and the urban fringes, they offer a prime opportunity for achieving smart growth goals, such as promoting spatial balance between jobs and housing. Furthermore, inner ring suburban housing is recognized for its ability to accommodate affordable and mixed-income housing development and revitalization. However, few policies exist to target the issues confronting inner ring suburbs. To prevent further deterioration and take advantage of housing opportunities offered by inner ring suburbs, the authors recommend considerations for infrastructure improvements, public private partnerships, fair-share housing policies, location efficient mortgages, and regional tax sharing. An “Urbanizing Tier System” that accounts for differentiated development patterns throughout urban areas is also considered as an alternative to urban growth boundaries.

list-item.p: 68. Ryan, B. D., and R. Weber. 2007. “Valuing New Development in Distressed Urban Neighborhoods: Does Design Matter?” Journal of the American Planning Association 73 (1): 100–111.
Keywords: Illinois, infill, revitalization, property value

sec.p: Focusing on poor urban neighborhoods, Ryan and Weber analyze the influence of design on property values within the context of urban revitalization through new housing construction. The authors identify three distinct development types for analysis: traditional neighborhood design which includes conventional gridiron streets, enclaves that tend to be more isolated from existing development, and infill development that is designed to fit in with the existing built environment. The study focuses on Chicago census tracts which are at least 2 miles from the central business district, with poverty rate exceeding 20 percent. Construction permit data are used to identify the location of 823 parcels where new housing was built. Cook County tax assessment records were then used to determine the assessed value of these parcels. Cluster analysis establishes the key independent variable of neighborhood design with specific design characteristics assigned to each category, thus also allowing the authors to explore what elements of each design scheme were most influential. Data are analyzed in a standard hedonic model which reveals infill housing to be the most highly valued. Values for enclave development are shown to be 22–29 percent less than those of infill developments, and traditional neighborhood development had values of 22–27 percent less than those of infill developments. The authors interpret these findings as evidence that consumers desire and are willing to pay a premium for new housing that is integrated into existing development patterns.

list-item.p: 69. Schill, M. H., I. G. Ellen, A. E. Schwartz, and I. Voicu. 2002. “Revitalizing Inner-City Neighborhoods: New York City’s Ten-Year Plan.” Housing Policy Debate 13 (3): 529–66.
Keywords: affordability, New York City, revitalization, spillover

sec.p: This article looks at the impacts on housing prices from the neighborhood revitalization effort of New York City’s Ten-Year Plan. This program was initiated in the 1980s to address issues of homelessness, housing affordability, and vacant properties. Extended years beyond its original time frame, the program has constructed or rehabilitated more than 180,000 housing units in distressed neighborhoods. Considering these successes, the authors pose the questions of what have been the effects on the prices of nearby properties (spillover effects), how the size of developments affects these prices, and how the effects vary between owner occupied and rental projects. To do this, 1987–2000 data are obtained from the city department of finance, and a sample of over 293,000 housing sales for 1980–1999 is obtained from the Real Property Assessment database. GIS overlay is used to estimate proximity of these properties to the project sites. Because these projects generally occurred in distressed neighborhoods, large price gaps exist between these neighborhoods and the city average. Results suggest that revitalization projects helped shrink the gap by 1.8 percent for projects of 1–50 units, 3.3 percent for those with 50–100 units, and 7.4 percent for those with more than 100 units. While homeowners, landlords, and vacant land holders benefited from this, some renters have experienced increased rent burdens.

list-item.p: 70. Sohmer, R. 1999. “Downtown Housing as an Urban Redevelopment Tool: Hype or Hope?” Housing Policy Debate 10 (2): 477–505.
Keywords: displacement, growth management, revitalization, urban growth boundary, zoning

sec.p: This edited transcript from the 1998 Association of Collegiate Schools of Planning captures the discussion of a group of planning scholars on the future of downtown housing as well as its advantages and disadvantages. Consensus has been reached that housing is an important component of urban revitalization, and downtown living has the potential to cater to the housing needs of the growing demographic groups of empty-nesters and young professionals. Downtown housing often utilizes a building stock that is ripe for conversion, and promotes high-density uses. However, challenges are also acknowledged, such as zoning regulations, tenure mismatches, lack of downtown development experiences, displacement issues, and garnering public support for downtown housing. The common concerns of potential downtown housing consumers include amenities, parking, and safety. Growth management strategies, such as urban growth boundaries, are discussed for their potential impacts on both downtown residential development and leapfrog developments. The success of downtown housing is seen to largely depend on marketing and the availability of subsidies.

list-item.p: 71. Steinacker, A. 2003. “Infill Development and Affordable Housing: Patterns from 1996-2000.” Urban Affairs Review 38 (4): 492–509.

sec.p: Urban infill is often seen as a means for economic redevelopment. However, it is also considered a source of gentrification and subsequent housing affordability problems. Noting the relevance of urban infill as part of the smart growth agenda, Steinacker addresses infill in terms of residential redevelopment and housing affordability. Through statistical analysis of the fifty largest US metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) over 1996–2000, this study discovers that infill development is positively associated with market rents, but negatively related to median income and housing affordability. Infill development is shown to occur on a greater scale in cities with expensive rental housing markets and low affordability rates. Therefore, while urban infill may serve as a viable mechanism for economic development, it may also be potentially detrimental to affordable housing opportunities.

sec.title: 7. Open Space Preservation
sec.p:
72. Acharya, G., and L. L. Bennett. 2001. “Valuing Open Space and Land-Use Patterns in Urban Watersheds.” Journal of Real Estate Finance and Economics 22 (2/3): 221–37.
Keywords: Connecticut, open space, property value
Using New Haven County, Connecticut’s watershed as a case study, the authors focus on the impacts of open space and other land use amenities on property values. Although many previous studies have addressed this question using urban and rural designation variables, this particular analysis is intended to offer new insights by considering open space proximity. To do this, a hedonic price model is chosen that relates housing prices (in logarithm form) to environmental attributes. Data used in this research include home sales transaction information for 4,000 New Haven County homes for the years of 1995 and 1997, demographic data from the 1990 Census, and 1990 US Geographical Survey land use data. The analysis demonstrates a significant and positive correlation between proximity to open space and residential property values, and a negative correlation between heterogeneous landscapes to property values. By utilizing distance variables, the authors state that more implicit values of land uses which account for proximity to amenities, such as open space, may be revealed.

list-item.p: 73. Bolitzer, B., and N. R. Netusil. 2000. “The Impact of Open Spaces on Property Values in Portland, Oregon.” Journal of Environmental Management 59: 185–93.
Keywords: Portland (Oregon), open space, property value

sec.p: Bolitzer and Netusil utilize three hedonic pricing models to determine the relationship between home values and existing open space in Portland, Oregon. The first investigates value effects for properties within 1,500 feet of an open space. The second model differentiates open space by type (public park, golf course, private park, or cemetery). The third model considers the magnitude effects of distance between the open space and a residential property, within the 1,500-feet buffer area. Using a log specification for the first model, a home within 1,500 feet of a 20-acre open space is expected to have a selling price of $1,247 more than a home that is not in proximity to an open space. When open space types are differentiated, public parks and golf courses are shown to have positive and significant effects, while private parks and cemeteries are not. The third model demonstrates the greatest, but insignificant, price effects from an open space within a half of a block. According to Bolitzer and Netusil, other benefits, such as improved water quality, are likely to result from the presence of open space, but such benefits are not likely to be reflected in housing values. The results indicate that increases in property tax values may be achieved through the protection of open space and offer the potential to offset the costs of open space preservation.

list-item.p: 74. Geoghegan, J. 2001. “The Value of Open Spaces in Residential Land Use.” Land Use Policy 19: 91–98.
Keywords: Maryland, open space, property value

sec.p: With the utilization of a hedonic regression model, Geoghegan examines the effects of proximity to open space on residential land values in Howard County, Maryland. Furthermore, effects are also differentiated on the basis of whether open space is classified as “permanent” or “developable.” The data set comes from the Maryland Office of Planning and provides transaction information for 5,599 home purchases occurring in Howard County between September 1993 and June 1996. It is predicted that the benefits of this proximity will be capitalized into a higher selling price for the home and that permanent open space will have larger effects than developable open space. The estimated coefficients for the hedonic model indicate a positive and statistically significant relationship between proximity to open space and residential property value. Furthermore, permanent open space is shown to command a higher premium than land that is open for future development. This suggests that open space preservation can potentially generate higher land tax revenues that could in turn be utilized to fund further conservation efforts.

list-item.p: 75. Irwin, E. G. 2002. “The Effects of Open Space on Residential Property Values.” Land Economics 78 (4): 465–80.
Keywords: Maryland, open space, spillover, property value

sec.p: This analysis considers the effects of open space on the values of residential property in central Maryland. According to Irwin, the spillover effects of open space on nearby residential property values vary depending on the use of the land and whether it is susceptible to future development or permanently protected. Utilizing 55,799 housing transaction records from the late 1990s, Irwin constructs a hedonic pricing model to test whether different types of open space generate different spillover effects. Privately owned conservation land and public open space are found to have a positive and significant effect on the value of neighboring properties in comparison to proximity to developable open space. For example, the conversion of 1 acre of developable pasture land to privately owned conservation land is expected to increase the mean value of neighboring residential property by 1.87 percent. Conversely, higher density and nonresidential land uses are found to have a significantly negative spillover effect with conversion to commercial space, resulting in an anticipated decline in value of 2.56 percent. These findings suggest that open space demand is motivated by the promise of no future development rather than open space amenities, such as biodiversity or scenic views.

list-item.p: 76. Kaufman, D. A., and N. R. Cloutier. 2006. “The Impact of Small Brownfields and Greenspaces on Residential Property Values.” Journal of Real Estate Finance Economics 33: 19–30.
Keywords: Brownfield, Kenosha (Wisconsin), revitalization, property value

sec.p: Kaufman and Cloutier’s study on the property effects of greenspaces and brownfields is unique from other research for two reasons. First, the authors use a hedonic model and simultaneously identify the price effects of both greenspaces and brownfields. Second, they use their findings to predict potential changes in property values if the brownfields were converted to greenspace. Kenosha’s Lincoln neighborhood in Wisconsin is used as a case study. This is a primarily working-class community that has suffered from both economic disinvestment and environmental degradation as a result of a declining manufacturing industry. At the time of the study, the neighborhood contained two abandoned industrial sites covering a combined area of 33.25 acres as well as a 44-acre city park. Real property values for 890 residential properties are obtained through city property tax assessment data. After demonstrating a negative relationship between brownfields and property values and a positive relationship between greenspace and property values, Kaufman and Cloutier proceed to determine the effects of remediation of brownfields into greenspace using an inverse distance model and a log distance model. Results of these two analyses suggest an average property value increase of $2,694 to $7,873. Therefore, collective property values of the Lincoln neighborhood have the potential to rise 2.4 to 7.01 million dollars if existing brownfields were to be converted to greenspace.

list-item.p: 77. Riddel, M. 2001. “A Dynamic Approach to Estimating Hedonic Prices for Environmental Goods: An Application to Open Space Purchase.” Land Economics 77 (4): 494–512.

sec.p: The cross-sectional hedonic model is a commonly used tool for evaluating the effects of policy and amenities on housing prices. However, Riddel challenges that these studies may be ill equipped for addressing environmental amenities which change over time, in contrast with the problematic assumption about a static equilibrium of housing market. Therefore, her study of the effects of Boulder, Colorado’s greenbelt program incorporates a model error correction approach that allows for endogenous environmental quality. The model evaluates time-series trends of environmental quality on the housing and labor markets. Locally collected data for the years of 1981 to 1995 are used to assess the effects of the municipally owned greenbelt. The model conveys that the program causes shifts in both the supply and demand curves which have resulted in housing prices rising by an estimated 3.75 percent. Furthermore, enhanced amenities offered by the greenbelt are deemed as responsible for a drop in average wages. However, it is also noted that the program actually encouraged residential development and leapfrogging, and thus the program did not meet its initial goal of hindering residential growth. Riddel concludes in recommending the advantages of a time-series approach and suggesting that the model may be useful in estimating the effects of other environmental policies.

list-item.p: 78. Wu, J., R. M. Adams, and A. J. Plantinga. 2004. “Amenities in an Urban Equilibrium Model: Residential Development in Portland, Oregon.” Land Economics 80 (1): 19–32.
Keywords: open space, Oregon, property value

sec.p: Identifying open space conversion as a strong growth management concern of the late 1990s, Wu et al. consider the effects of growth management on housing development and price in Multnomah County, Oregon, part of the Portland metropolitan area. The authors chose an urban equilibrium model to determine the effects of open space and other amenities on density and property value. Data for Multnomah County are obtained from a number of sources including the MetroScan real estate database, Portland’s Metro Regional Services agency, and the metro area’s geographic information system. The model suggests that households are willing to pay more for newer houses located closer to less developed areas. Higher values are associated with better views, further distance from industry, and less traffic congestion. Essentially, open space is demonstrated as a valued amenity and is often associated with lower housing densities. This leads to a dilemma for developers who are inclined to provide more housing on more valued lands which in turn increases density and consequently lowers housing prices.

sec.title: C. Impacts of Regulation on Housing Price and Affordability
sec.p:
79. Carlson, D., and S. Mathur. 2004. “Does Growth Management Aid or Thwart the Provision of Affordable Housing?” In Growth Management and Affordable Housing: Do they conflict? edited by A. Downs, 20–81. Washington, DC: The Brookings Institute.
Keywords: affordability, density, growth management, Maryland, New Jersey, smart growth, Washington
The purposes of this study are to analyze how growth management policies affect affordability. By considering a housing expense and income ratio, the authors explicitly look at housing affordability rather than housing price or value for low-to-moderate-income households. A household consuming more than 30 percent of their income is defined as unaffordable for a house. King County in Washington, Montgomery County in Maryland, and the New Jersey counties of Somerset and Middlesex have well-developed growth management policies, and are chosen for the study. Fairfax County, Virginia, adopts more traditional development policies, and is used as a comparison. Census data for the years 1990 and 2000 are used to determine percentages of income spent on housing in these counties. Results indicate that affordability of owner occupied housing units decreased for all growth management counties. Rental affordability decreased in the New Jersey counties, remained the same in King County, and increased in Montgomery County. The authors attribute Montgomery County’s success to its implementation of the Moderately Priced Dwelling Unit Program from 1974, which combines density bonuses with preservation measures. Results show that Farifax County had the largest improvement in affordability levels, but still had the highest affordable housing gaps.

list-item.p: 80. Glaeser, E., and J. Gyourko. 2002. “Zoning’s Steep Price.” Regulation 25 (3): 24–30.

sec.p: Glaeser and Gyourko state that the majority of US housing is priced relatively close to its cost of construction, suggesting that housing affordability problems may very well stem from poverty rather than housing costs. However, they also identify a number of markets with housing prices that greatly exceed construction costs, prompting the question of what drives prices so high in these places. The authors suggest that zoning plays a significant role in hindering the production of housing and consequently driving up its cost through a “zoning tax” which can force homeowners to consume larger than desired quantities of land. To validate this theory, statistical testing of data from the 1999 American Housing Survey is conducted to determine how housing prices correspond with regulation, population density, and lot sizes. The intensive value of land is determined by linear and logarithmic regressions of housing prices as a function of lot size and a number of other housing characteristics, while the extensive value is determined by differences between structural prices and housing costs. According to Glaeser and Gyourko, both methodologies should produce similar values in a free market. However, results reveal significant difference, suggesting a strong influence of regulation. Further analysis indicates expensive markets are not generally associated with higher densities, and regulation is responsible for housing price increases rather than high demand. Using these findings as support, the authors recommend zoning reform as an important component to lowering the costs of housing.

list-item.p: 81. Glaeser, E. L., and J. Gyourko. 2003. “The Impact of Building Restriction on Housing Affordability.” Federal Reserve Bank of New York Economic Policy Review 9 (2): 21–39.

sec.p: According to Glaeser and Gyourko, American perceptions of a housing affordability crisis are distorted by other poverty-related issues. Instead, housing costs are generally in line with construction costs in most parts of the country, with the exception of some extremely expensive markets, such as New York City. This article explores the correlation between these high-priced housing markets and land use regulations to determine their role in inflicting higher housing prices. Data from the 1999 American Housing Survey, 2000 US Census, and R. S. Means construction cost data are used to determine how construction costs differ from total housing costs across US regions. Results indicate that housing prices tend to highly exceed their respective construction costs in the West. To explain why housing prices are higher in certain regions, the relationship to zoning is considered, particularly in the context of density, regulatory barriers, and time constraints. The stringency of zoning regulations is found to be highly correlated to increasing housing prices. For example, an increase in the amount of time required to obtain a zoning permit are shown to bring 15 percent of a city’s housing stock into a more expensive price range. Glaeser and Gyourko conclude that reducing the costs associated with zoning would have a much higher impact on housing prices than subsidized housing programs. However, they also acknowledge that this study is focused on regulation costs, rather than benefits, and that existing homeowners are likely to experience the negative effect of decreased housing values as a result of new zoning policies that would allow for more affordable housing in their communities. Thus, compensatory measures would likely be needed to subsidize this loss.

list-item.p: 82. Landis, J. D. 2006. “Growth Management Revisited: Efficacy, Price Effects, and Displacement.” Journal of the American Planning Association 72 (4): 411–30.
Keywords: California, displacement, growth management, housing price

sec.p: In this study of growth management in California, Landis evaluates the growth management techniques of annual housing caps, residential adequate public facilities ordinances (APFO), urban growth boundaries, annexation limits, and voter-enacted supermajority approval requirements. With a strong emphasis on housing, this evaluation explores the areas of housing supply and demand, production, pricing, and displacement. Using GIS and regression analysis, Landis makes comparisons between California cities and finds that cities with local growth management controls demonstrate more success in meeting housing production demands than those without such measures. Findings also indicate that growth management policies both directly and indirectly raise housing prices. While displacement due to growth management is positive and statistically significant, it is not considered substantially large. Landis concludes that when growth management policies are designed to allow for the required level of housing production, such measures will not be the primary source of increased housing prices and rents.

list-item.p: 83. Green, R. K. 1999. “Land Use Regulation and the Price of Housing in a Suburban Wisconsin County.” Journal of Housing Economics 8: 144–59.
Keywords: affordability, housing price, Wisconsin, zoning

sec.p: The intent of Green’s study is to describe how land use restrictions affect housing costs, including its distributional impacts, as well as the magnitude. Green notes that previous research has largely indicated that zoning increases the cost of housing. This study examines impacts of land use restrictions in Waukesha County, Wisconsin on both price and affordability. Affordability is defined as the availability of homes costing less than $75,000. Data are obtained from a 1992 study of zoning codes and summary files collected in the 1990 Population and Housing Census, and a least squares regression model is used for analysis. There are six policies designated as regulatory variables: subdivision lot width requirements, frontage setbacks, minimum street widths, sidewalk requirements, curb and gutter requirements, and the prohibition of mobile homes. Both mobile home provisions and minimal width requirements have significant effects. Regulations forbidding mobile homes increased the price of homes from 7.1 to 8.5 percent and decreased the stock of affordable housing by 6 to 8 percent. For every additional 10 feet of required lot length, prices are found to increase by 6.1 to 7.8 percent and reduce the share of affordable housing by 3 to 4 percent. Noting that the impacts of such regulations fall most heavily on low-income groups, Green states that any further tightening of land use restrictions will likely result in increased burdens for Waukesha County’s growing population of entry-level workers.

list-item.p: 84. Green, R. K., S. Malpezzi, and S. K. Mayo. 2005. “Metropolitan-Specific Estimates of the Price Elasticity of Supply of Housing, and Their Sources.” The American Economic Review 95 (2): 334–38.
Keywords: density, regulation stringency, price elasticity

sec.p: In this article, Green et al. estimate supply elasticities for individual metropolitan areas and explain differences that exist between these areas, particularly in terms of the stringency of environmental and land use regulations. Data on forty-five metropolitan areas for 1979–1996 are used to determine elasticity estimates through first-stage regression. These elasticities are then used as a dependent variable in a cross-sectional analysis that integrates a number of relevant land market influences including land use regulation. The most elastic markets are found to be in sprawling cities, such as Dallas and Charlotte. The lowest elasticities are found in areas with slower growth, geographic constraints, or compact development patterns, for instance, Providence, San Francisco, Miami, and Chicago. While all stringently regulated cities are found to have less elastic markets, more elastic cities demonstrate more relaxed regulations. However, some cities without stringent regulations demonstrated low price elasticity which was generally explained by slow growth. Higher densities are also deemed to significantly influence price elasticity regardless of whether it was a result of land use regulation or other factors, such as geographic constraints.

list-item.p: 85. Ihlanfeldt, K. R. 2006. “The Effect of Land Use Regulation on Housing and Land Prices.” Journal of Urban Economics 61: 420–35.
Keywords: Florida, housing price, land use regulation, single-family housing

sec.p: In this study, Ihlanfeldt estimates the effects of the restrictiveness of land use regulations on the price of single-family housing and vacant residential land in the state of Florida over 2000–2002. Data are obtained from local property tax roles for twenty-five Florida counties, along with 2000 census data and a 2001 survey of local planners regarding the stringency of local land use restrictions. These land use policies are then gauged through a “restrictiveness index” which subjectively measures the stringency of the restrictions. Analysis is conducted through a reduced form price equation which is also inclusive of a number of other housing characteristics. Results suggest that newly constructed homes will be larger in jurisdictions with more regulations, because regulatory costs are easier to be shifted to homebuyers. In addition, competition between jurisdictions reduces affordability, and restrictive regulations can strongly affect developer’s costs in ways that extend beyond increasing housing costs.

list-item.p: 86. Malpezzi, S. 2002. “Urban Regulation, the ‘New Economy,’ and Housing Prices.” Housing Policy Debate 13 (2): 323–49.
Keywords: housing price, land use regulation, high-tech economic activities

sec.p: This article considers the influences of high-tech economic activities (the new economy) and land use regulations on housing prices. Seeking to unveil the characteristics of “high-tech localities,” including their association to land use regulations and housing prices, Malpezzi designates “high tech” areas using a previously established index (DeVol, 1999) which accounts for the location quotient of high-tech industries, such as biotechnology and electronics. “Regulated” areas are designated by an index designed by Malpezzi (1996) to account for factors, such as the zoning process and infrastructural adequacy. A number of discursive and descriptive methods are used to test and validate the hypothesis that concentrations of high-tech activities and land use regulations are correlated to higher housing prices. Regression analysis is conducted to test the hypothesis that regulation may be a luxury good demanded by high income groups in localities influenced by the high-tech economy. However, results fail to confirm this hypothesis ceteris paribus.

list-item.p: 87. Netusil, N. 2005. “The Effect of Environmental Zoning and Amenities on Property Values: Portland, Oregon.” Land Economics 81 (2): 227–46.

sec.p: This study examines the effects of environmental zoning on property values in Portland, Oregon. Netusil states that his study differs from many of its predecessors in the fact that it separately identifies and estimates the development and amenity effects of zoning. A hedonic price model is used to study how environmental zoning and proximity to environmental amenities affect single-family home prices in Multnomah County, Oregon over 1999–2001. Multnomah comprises an area of 92,150 acres, 9,395 of which are designated as an environmental conservation overlay zone (C-zone) and 9,776 as an environmental protection overlay zone (P-zone). P-zones are regulated with the most stringent development regulations, only allowing for new construction under circumstances of “demonstrated public need and benefit.” Approximately 3.42 percent of properties in this study are located within a C- or P-zone. In addition to environmental zoning, amenities such as trees, wetlands, rivers, streams, golf courses, and park access are included in the study. Results varied with locations and access to amenities. Some locations demonstrate statistically insignificant effects of zoning on prices and some are associated with decreased values in environmentally protected zones. Locations in protected zones with good proximity to environmental amenities demonstrate higher values.

list-item.p: 88. Quigley, J. M., and S. Raphael. 2005. “Regulation and the High Cost of Housing in California.” The American Economic Review 95 (2): 323–28.
Keywords: California, housing price, land use regulation

sec.p: This article examines the effects of land use regulation on housing prices in California.
