Using the 1990 and 2000 Census Public Use Microdata Samples and a survey of land use officials for 407 California cities, the authors explore the relationships between the stringency of land use policy and housing price, housing stock growth, and housing supply elasticity. From the survey, fifteen growth-control measures are identified, and the number of such measures enforced by each city is used to determine regulation stringency. Bivariate regression of these data finds that the addition of each regulatory measure increased the price of owner-occupied housing by 3 percent and increased the cost of rental housing by 1 percent in 1990. In 2000, owner-occupied housing was shown to increase in price by 4.5 for each additional regulation and 2.3 percent in rental housing. Further exploration of the data indicates negative effects from growth restrictions on housing stock growth as well as housing supply elasticity for strongly regulated cities.

list-item.p: 89. Quigley, J. M., and L. A. Rosenthal. 2005. “The Effects of Land Use Regulation on the Price of Housing: What Do We Know? What Can We Learn?” Cityscape 8 (1): 69–101.
Keywords: housing price, land use regulation

sec.p: Quigley and Rosenthal comprehensively review the history of restrictive land use policy and discuss the methodologies and findings of empirical studies focusing on the relationship of these policies to housing price. The existing body of research is first categorized and critiqued by type. Monopoly zoning studies, which focus on governmental fragmentation, are described as being beneficial in explaining how government concentration can raise housing prices, but are said not to be inclusive of a much needed analysis of regulatory mechanisms. Surveys and place-specific studies dating back to the 1970s are considered for their contributions in explaining the more specific roles that land use policies have played in altering housing prices. While the authors state that this wealth of literature provides insight on a number of considerations, they explicitly state that no firm conclusions about this relationship can be made due to methodological factors such as difficulty in establishing definitive measurements of regulation. Taking this into consideration, the authors conclude that resources should be invested in developing research tools, such as surveys, that can better conceptualize regulation which will in turn enhance the general understanding of the effects of regulation on housing price.

list-item.p: 90. Schill, M. H. 2005. “Regulations and Housing Development: What We Know.” Cityscape: A Journal of Policy Development and Research 8 (1): 5–19.
Keywords: affordability, impact fee, housing price, regulation, smart growth

sec.p: To explore how government regulation has affected escalating housing prices, Schill discusses the concept of regulatory development barriers and presents potential alternatives. While regulations, such as zoning, impact fees, environmental regulations, and other building or infrastructural requirements, may often represent a concern of the common good, Schill states that negative externalities are produced in the form of housing prices, and in many instances these policies often create scarcity and enhance concentrated wealth. A review of existing literature further illustrates that housing costs are increasing due to substantial expenses of money and time which result from complex systems of regulation. Schill states that a strong interest toward maintaining current policies, as well as a lack of knowledge on the subject, is likely to limit the expansion of opportunities for affordable housing. Although smart growth presents a means for defeating some barriers to affordable housing, it also has the potential to create new ones through the reduction of developable land.

list-item.p: 91. Schuetz, J. 2009. “No Renters in My Suburban Backyard: Land-use Regulation and Rental Housing.” Journal of Policy Analysis and Management 28 (2): 296–320.

sec.p: This article sets out to discover whether local land use regulations have limited production and raised the cost of rental housing in Massachusetts. Massachusetts makes an interesting venue for studying regulatory impacts on rental housing because rents there are well above the national average, new construction of rental housing is sparse, and Massachusetts has a long history of strict land use regulations. In order to deal with the endogeneity issue of zoning when identifying the effects of land use regulations, the author used an instrumental variable to estimate the effects of local land use regulations on the rental market. She first regressed current regulations on historical municipal characteristics. Then through regression analysis she estimated the effects of the instrument variable on multifamily permits and rents. Data were pulled from local zoning measures in 187 cities in eastern and central Massachusetts. The author found that regulations limited the development of new rental housing. But the effect of zoning on the cost of rent was unclear. These conclusions suggest that neither demand-side nor supply-side subsidies would aid lower income families in relocating to more prosperous neighborhoods.

list-item.p: 92. Somerville, C. T., and C. J. Mayer. 2003. “Government Regulation and Changes in the Affordable Housing Stock.” Economic Policy Review 9 (2): 45–62.

sec.p: Noting that policies benefiting suburban homeowners may have unintended negative externalities for low-income renters, Somerville and Mayer consider the effects of government regulation upon housing affordability. Their analysis offers a unique perspective in that it determines housing affordability by looking at a housing stock that filters to low-income renters as new housing becomes available to the affluent. Rental information is derived from the 1984–1994 American Housing Surveys, and regulation variables are established from a prior (1991) survey of sixty cities. Using a measure of 30 percent of income for households earning less than 35 percent of median income to determine the affordability of housing, affordable units within the survey are analyzed to determine if they remained affordable, became unaffordable, became owner-occupied, or were demolished. Multinomial logit analysis was performed to determine if regulations had any effect on such changes. The results suggest that affordable units had a greater chance of filtering up when regulation was present. This means that when new construction was constrained, affordable rental units were more susceptible to being converted to unaffordable rentals and owner-occupied units or being demolished so that land could be utilized for new units. The authors conclude that the effects of land use decisions are not limited to raising housing costs to homeowners and that low-income families also bear the costs of regulation.

list-item.p: 93. Wassmer, R. W., and M. C. Baass. 2006. “Does a More Centralized Urban Form Raise Housing Prices?” Journal of Policy Analysis and Management 25 (2): 439–62.

sec.p: This article attempts to clarify the ambiguousness on the topic of whether urban areas with more centralized populations have higher housing costs. The authors believe that the results have important implications for smart growth’s goal of increased population densities. Utilizing a hedonic regression model, the authors determine the relationship between centralization and housing price for 452 cities. The presence of houses costing over $300,000 (based on 2000 housing prices) are also considered to determine the effect on upper priced homes. The results report an expected 2–3 percent decrease in housing prices for every 10 percent increase in population centralization. Increases in centralization also decreased the presences of upper priced homes. The authors theorize this to be attributable to households occupying smaller houses on smaller lots in more centralized areas.

sec.title: D. Other Issues Related to Low- and Moderate-income Population
1. Displacement
sec.p:
94. Larsen, K. 2005. “New Urbanism’s Role in Inner-City Neighborhood Revitalization.” Housing Studies 20 (5): 795–813.
Keywords: displacement, equity, gentrification, HOPE VI, new urbanism, Orlando (Florida), revitalization, smart growth
This study serves as a case study which evaluates urban revitalization efforts in Orlando, Florida’s Parramore and Eola neighborhoods, two low-income communities that have been plagued with disinvestment and urban decay. Beginning in the mid-1980s, both communities underwent revitalization initiatives that were heavily influenced by New Urbanism. While Parramore’s redevelopment plan has extended public and commercial facilities, it also resulted in the net displacement of 239 homes and 940 residents during the 1990s. Although housing values and homeownership rates in Parramore both remained low throughout this period, Larsen states that community conditions are ripe for gentrification to occur. Conversely, in Eola, where hundreds of luxury homes have been developed, rents and homeownership rates have increased along with demographic changes that strongly imply gentrification. While strategies, such as mixed-income/tenure housing and HOPE VI redevelopment projects have been implemented in Eola and Parramore, Larsen states revitalization efforts in these communities have failed to address social equity in terms of affordable housing and gentrification. To remedy these issues, Larsen advocates for redevelopment plans and planning policies that are pro-active, comprehensive, and based upon resident participation.

list-item.p: 95. Levine, N. 1999. “The Effects of Local Growth Controls on Regional Housing Production and Population Redistribution in California.” Urban Studies 36 (12): 2047–68.
Keywords: California, displacement, growth management, property value

sec.p: This study uses 1989 and 1992 surveys of 490 California cities and counties to examine the effects of local growth control measures on net housing production from the years of 1980 to 1990. It is intended to test whether displacement occurred and whether local growth restrictions redistributed development to less regulated areas. Levine’s results support that growth control measures enacted between the years of 1979 and 1980 have resulted in a net housing reduction of 884 units, and 33 percent of new housing in California has been redistributed to less regulated areas. These results are also consistent with demographic and housing data from the 1980 and 1990 US Census. The growth control measures are found to be associated with a number of indicators of displacement including reductions in the availability of rental housing, increases in rents and home ownership values, increasing shares of higher-income households, and decreases in minority population. According to Levine, these trends demonstrate a need for greater housing considerations in local growth management plans.

list-item.p: 96. Nelson, A. C., C. J. Dawkins, and T. W. Sanchez. 2007. The Social Impacts of Urban Containment. Burlington, VT: Ashgate Publishing.
Keywords: affordability, gentrification, Portland (Oregon), housing price, urban containment, mandatory housing

sec.p: Gentrification, segregation, and affordability are the primary focus of chapters 5, 6, and 7 of Nelson et al.’s The Social Impacts of Urban Containment. To explore claims of gentrification, the authors pose the question of whether land use practices in Portland, Oregon, have resulted in gentrification which is operationalized as the percent of units converting to owner-occupied status from 1990 to 2000. Using data from the US Census Bureau, tax assessment records, and GIS, binary logit regression is performed to predict the likelihood that a single-family residential unit will convert from rental to owner-occupied. Fourteen percent of Portland’s single-family rental housing converted to owner-occupied housing from 1990 to 2000 with such conversions most commonly occurring in neighborhoods with large houses, low incomes, and large minority populations. Nelson et al. further consider the impacts of urban containment and mandatory housing elements in shaping spatial patterns of racial segregation through an analysis of dissimilarity indexes. During the 1990s, the Portland metropolitan area exhibited an exceptionally high decrease in dissimilarity of 24.5 percent. Using 1985–2000 American Housing Survey, multiple regression models are also performed to analyze how urban containment relates to owner-occupied housing. Results demonstrate greater willingness of homeowners to pay for housing as the amount of time that growth management in their community has been enforced increases. In terms of rental housing, 1999 and 2003 National Housing Survey data are used to analyze the availability of affordable units for 1999. To explain whether these units, remained affordable, became unaffordable, became owner occupied, or were demolished between 1999 and 2003, multinomial logistic regression is performed. Findings suggest an association between urban containment and a lower probability of conversions of affordable rental units to other housing types, suggesting that urban containment may also enhance affordability through the preservation of rental housing.

sec.title: 2. Social Equity
sec.p:
97. Agyeman, J., and T. Evans. 2003. “Toward Just Sustainability in Urban Communities: Building Equity Rights with Sustainable Solutions.” The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science 590: 35–53.
Keywords: equity, location efficient mortgage, transit oriented development
This article considers how sustainability and environmental justice interact within the context of practical urban planning. The authors state that clean and healthy environments should not be reserved for only selected members of a society and investigate ways that such a balance can be achieved. Through a review of literature, the authors list location efficient mortgages and community housing incentives as the examples that are somewhat inclusive of both sustainability and justice. The authors further point out that the majority of sustainability goals are absent of a true environmental justice component. However, there are examples successfully melding together these critical concepts, such as advocacy groups that promote energy efficiency and transit-oriented housing development. With a current absence of government policy in either of these realms, activism, cooperation, and community organizations may hold the potential steps of bringing the notions of sustainability and environmental justice to a more prominent status in US policy.

list-item.p: 98. Calavita, N., and K. Grimes. 1998. “Inclusionary Housing in California: The Experience of 2 Decades.” Journal of the American Planning Association 64 (2): 150–68.

sec.p: This article chronicles the history of inclusionary housing policies in the state of California, where localities have been required to adopt affordable housing elements in their general plans since the early 1970s. Early inclusionary housing policies were implemented alongside growth management polices, such as housing caps, to countervail negative impacts on affordability levels. However, the authors note that inclusionary housing policies have been interpreted differently by varying political administrations throughout the years. This study utilizes data from the early to mid 1990s, including a telephone survey, a mail survey, and personal interviews of San Diego city officials, to describe how inclusionary housing elements have been implemented. Inclusionary housing policies are primarily clustered around the state’s largest costal cities. The majority of these policies require 10–15 percent of housing units in a new development to be affordable for low or moderate income families, although some localities required as much as 50 percent of new units to be reserved for affordable housing. While many of the requirements mandate affordable units to be evenly dispersed and similar in appearance to market rate units, reductions in square footage and amenities have been permitted in these affordable units. In-lieu fees have also been offered to developers in many communities as an alternative to providing affordable housing and ranged from $600 to $36,000 per unit. While the authors commend these policies for helping to produce approximately 24,000 new affordable units over the two decades studied, they also note that the needs of the very low income have been overlooked in favor of moderate-income homebuyers and that greater quantities of affordable housing will have to be provided to keep up with California’s growing housing demands.

list-item.p: 99. Ihlanfeldt, K. R. 2004. “Exclusionary Land-use Regulations within Suburban Communities: A Review of the Evidence and Policy Prescriptions.” Urban Studies 41 (2): 261–83.
Keywords: growth management, regulation, segregation, urban growth boundary, zoning

sec.p: In this extensive literature review, Ihlanfelt studies the effects of land use regulation on housing costs, the nature of such costs, whether such policies discriminate against minorities, and whether they incur a spatial mismatch between jobs and housing. Through this review, Ihlanfeldt deduces that land use policies are found to increase the cost of housing. A review of spillover externality and construction studies demonstrates that these reductions are a result of supply restrictions rather than increased demand due to increased amenities. In terms of racial and socioeconomic exclusion, Ihlanfeldt’s review finds that white and more affluent neighborhoods tend to adopt more stringent exclusionary policies. However, urban growth boundaries are cited as a potential tool for reducing racial and economic barriers because they promote the infill of traditionally segregated neighborhoods. Ihlanfelt also investigates whether such regulations are motivated by a desire for exclusion and finds a consensus in the existing literature that instead fiscal considerations most frequently motivate land use regulations. While the significance of spatial mismatch factors is indeterminable, Ihlanfelt does find that restrictive land uses may diminish economic opportunity for low-income populations.

list-item.p: 100. Nelson, A. C., T. W. Sanchez, and C. J. Dawkins. 2004. “The Effect of Urban Containment and Mandatory Housing Elements on Racial Segregation in U.S. Metropolitan Areas, 1990–2000.” Journal of Urban Affairs 26 (3): 339–50.

sec.p: While zoning and other traditional land use restrictions have played a role in both racial and socioeconomic exclusion, Nelson et al. hypothesize that urban containment and affordable housing policies have aided in racial residential desegregation during the 1990s. This article explores the nationwide effects of these policies on racial segregation patterns from 1990 to 2000. To achieve this goal, segregation change is calculated using the index of dissimilarity, which measures what percentage of a racial group would have to move to a different census tract to achieve an even distribution across all census tracts. Data from a 2000 to 2002 mail and telephone survey of metropolitan housing organizations and statewide housing policy mandates are utilized to determine if an urban containment policy was present and if it was accompanied by housing elements. Data are analyzed through ordinary least squares regression, with socioeconomic, demographic, regional, and policy factors being controlled for. The effects of mandatory housing elements are not found statistically significant. However, the African American desegregation rates were 1.4 percent higher in municipalities with strong urban containment policy than those without such polices. When omitting for regional effects, this difference increased to 2.3 percent. The authors conclude that urban containment accelerates racial desegregation between Caucasians and African Americans.

list-item.p: 101. Nguyen, M. T. 2007. “Local Growth Control at the Ballot Box: Real Effects or Symbolic Politics?” Journal of Urban Affairs 29 (2): 129–47.
Keywords: California, growth management, multifamily housing, segregation

sec.p: In this California study, Nguyen probes the effectiveness of local, voter-determined, growth controls in slowing housing growth and whether such measures have exclusionary implications. California ballot measure data for the years 1986–1999, along with city-level housing and demographic data are used to construct eight multiple regression models that compare sociodemographic and housing changes in 84 cities that voted in local growth controls to 337 cities that did not enact such measures. The authors hypothesize that cities with ballot box growth controls will have slower rates of housing growth as well as slower rates of growth for multifamily housing, rental housing, and minority populations, but higher rates of median income growth. Results indicate that ballot box growth controls do significantly slow housing growth and are more likely to be adopted in cities with higher rates of wealth, homeownership, residential stability, and Caucasian populations. However, growth control measures were not demonstrated to significantly change the growth of multifamily units and to actually increase the number of rental units. In terms of demographics, ballot box measures are shown to have no effect on African American growth rates, but coincided with an increase in the Caucasian population and a reduction in Hispanic populations.

list-item.p: 102. Pendall, R. 2000. “Local Land Use Regulation and the Chain of Exclusion.” Journal of the American Planning Association 66 (2): 125–41.
Keywords: segregation, urban growth boundary, zoning

sec.p: Noting that growth management policy emerged in an era when exclusionary zoning polices were most strongly challenged, Pendall offers this study as an exploration of the relationship between land use regulations and housing exclusion for minority and low-income households. Using data collected from a mail survey of 1,510 US local governments and census data for the years of 1980 and 1990, Pendall examines the exclusionary effects of low-density zoning, building permit caps, building permit moratoria, adequate infrastructure ordinances, urban growth boundaries, and the prohibition of annexation. Using independent samples T-tests and least squares regression, Pendall finds a strong connection between low-density zoning and the exclusion of African Americans and Hispanics. Residential building caps are also significantly correlated to lower levels of Hispanic residents. Furthermore, growth boundaries and moratoria are shown to be associated with low percentages of minority populations. According to Pendall, low-density zoning has exemplified the strongest and most historic connections to racially based housing exclusion.

list-item.p: 103. Porter, D. R. 2008. Managing Growth in America's Communities. Island Press: Washington.
Keywords: affordability, equity, growth management, nongovernmental institutions

sec.p: Chapter seven of Porter’s comprehensive volume on American growth management focuses on the issues housing affordability and environmental equity. Housing affordability disparities are perpetuated by a number of economic and social trends, including the development of expensive bedroom communities as well as the job-population spatial mismatch. While sustainable development and smart growth advocates have expressed interest in addressing these imbalances and inequalities, Porter states that social and economic concerns have been largely underscored. Nongovernmental institutions have had to take a more important role in affordable housing provision, with the declines in units provided by the US department of Housing and Urban Development and the inability of the Community Development Block Grant program to provide long-term housing strategies. Furthermore, fair-share housing programs and other affordable housing requirements have not proven successful in a number of communities due to opposition from homeowners. To challenge these obstacles and to better accommodate both growth management and affordable housing, Porter recommends a number of strategies including inclusionary housing, housing trust funds, community land trusts, and the streamlining of local housing development regulations.

list-item.p: 104. Ruddiman, E. P. 2007. “Is Smart Growth Fair Growth: Do Urban Growth Boundaries Keep Out Racial Minorities.” PhD diss. Georgia State University.
Keywords: segregation, smart growth, urban growth boundary

sec.p: Ruddiman’s dissertation explores the relationship between racial exclusion and urban growth boundaries (UGB). Using forty-three matched pairs of municipalities with and without urban growth boundaries, Ruddiman draws comparisons of housing trends though consideration of changes in African American and Hispanic populations as well as changes in indexes of dissimilarity. Multivariate regression is also used to reveal the effect of growth boundaries on racial housing patterns. Data for the dissertation focus on the 1990–2000 time period and come from a number of sources including the US census, the Lewis Mumford Center, and prior research including Pendall’s 2002 study on racial exclusion. Ruddiman’s findings indicate that municipalities with UGBs have higher indexes of black–white racial dissimilarity than those without UGBs. Furthermore, UGBs are shown to increase these levels of dissimilarity between 1990 and 2000. However, differences in mean changes of dissimilarity between areas with and without UGBs between 1990 and 2000 are not found to differ significantly and levels of black-white racial dissimilarity appear to be converging. The presence of UGBs is demonstrated to have no effect on segregation between whites and Hispanics. Furthermore, UGBs are not shown to have any effect on the in-migration or out-migration of minorities in the municipalities included in this study. Therefore, Ruddiman presents her largely mixed findings as a challenge to both studies which advocate UGBs as a means of alleviating segregation as well as those which warn they may perpetuate it.

sec.title: 1. Market Profitability
sec.p:
105. Blackman, A., and A. Krupnick. 2001. “Location-Efficient Mortgages: Is the Rationale Sound?” Journal of Policy Analysis and Management 20 (4): 633–49.
Keywords: Chicago, location efficient mortgage
This article discusses the potential viability of the Fannie Mae Foundation’s location-efficient mortgage (LEM) pilot program of the late 1990s. This 100-million dollar program offered households in Chicago, Los Angeles, Portland, San Francisco, and Seattle the opportunity to borrow higher than normally permitted amounts of money and make lower than normally required down payments for the purchase of homes in communities offering free automobile access to jobs and other amenities. This easement in lending guidelines is justified by the notion that reductions in commuting costs will free up larger portions of household income to be spent on housing expenses. Blackman and Krupnick note that this policy is appealing because it offers incentives for those who chose to pursue more sustainable living standards. However, they question the implications of this lending strategy for mortgage default and use regression analysis to determine potential effects on the default rate. This test is based on data from 8,000 federally insured home loans that were issued in Chicago between 1988 and 1992 and matched with census household data on location efficiency as defined by proximity to job concentrations and other urban activities. Results indicated that no statistically significant relationship existed between the probability of mortgage default and location efficiency. These findings suggest that LEMs may increase mortgage default rates and therefore incur costs to the lender, making the LEM less appealing to mainstream secondary mortgage providers. However, Blackman and Krupnick conclude that these costs may be outweighed by the potential benefits of more sustainable development patterns.

list-item.p: 106. Brueckner, J. K. 2000. “Urban Sprawl: Diagnosis and Remedies.” International Regional Science Review 23 (2): 160–71.
Keywords: growth management, impact fee, housing price, urban growth boundary

sec.p: Brueckner’s analysis of urban sprawl focuses on how the implementation of growth management tools, such as urban growth boundaries (UGBs) and impact fees, can affect development patterns and the housing market. Brueckner states that the true costs of sprawl are often not accurately accounted for by the land market, but also demonstrates that regulation can swing the pendulum too far in the opposite direction and cause land prices to exceed their true value. For example, UGBs can cause needless development restrictions and unnecessarily high housing price escalation as exemplified by claims of excessive housing prices in Portland, Oregon. Therefore, according to Brueckner, UGBs should be set with great caution and proper consideration of land market dynamics. Properly determined development taxes, congestion tolls, and impact fess are recommended as solutions that can place the most accurate and fair price on sprawl to its consumers.

list-item.p: 107. Chatman, D., and N. Voorhoeve. 2010. “The Transportation-Credit Mortgage: A Post-Mortem.” Housing Policy Debate 20 (3): 355–82.
Keywords: location-efficient mortgage, smart commute mortgage, transit oriented communities

sec.p: Defunct location-efficient mortgage (LEM) and smart commute mortgage (SCM) programs allow home buyers to borrow larger than normal amounts for housing in areas with close proximity to public transit or with other “location efficient” characteristics. The programs contain the goals of increasing the share of households with access to public transportation, increasing housing supply in areas near transit systems and walkable neighborhoods, and increasing homeownership among low- and moderate- income households. Fannie Mae has ended these programs in 2006. The authors revaluated the program and discussed whether or not the program should be renewed. They pointed out that one problem of the program is that it overestimated potential costs of the program by not including certain neighborhood characteristics. Further, the authors noted that buyers receiving these mortgages were more susceptible to default than traditional homebuyers. Based on interview information with lenders and officials, the authors identified several reasons for the low number of originated loans under these programs, including (1) limited participation by large national lenders, (2) low demand for LEMs and SCMs, (3) availability of more competitive loan products, (4) real estate prices that exceeded Fannie Mae loan limits, (5) fear of unpredicted changes in employment patterns, and (6) passive transit agency involvement. The authors also examined 118 Fannie Mae loans and found that the actual amount of loans borrowers received were normally $27,717 less than they would have qualified for under conventional home loan terms. Borrowers with lower credit scores were found to have received an average interest rate that was 3 percent lower than what they would have qualified for. The transit-friendly communities in which LEM and SCM consumers purchased homes were also noted as having deficiencies in meeting their social goals of reducing sprawl and increasing low-income homeownership because buyers still preferred use automobile transit. Furthermore, increasing mortgage limits might drive up housing prices in areas with high demand. The authors suggested a more effective program by offering lower interest rate in lieu of higher loan approvals and revamping the program to provide information on the benefits of proximity to transit.

list-item.p: 108. Gihring, T. A. 1999. “Incentive Property Taxation: A Potential Tool for Urban Growth Management.” Journal of the American Planning Association 65 (1): 62–79.

sec.p: In this article, Gihring proposes land value taxation as a potentially viable alternative for achieving growth management goals. Such a system would essentially apply two property tax rates; one for structural value and another for land value. Thus, two-rate taxation would more accurately capture the development potential of land, rather than its underdeveloped value. According to Gihring, anticipated benefits include discouraging land banking, promoting urban infill, and discouraging sprawl, while at the same time restraining rising residential land prices and shifting property tax burdens away from homeowners. To test the viability of this proposed solution, Gihring considers the hypothetical fiscal effects of implementing two-rate taxation in Clark County, Washington, a quickly growing segment of the Portland, Oregon, metropolitan area. The results of this simulation reveal that a two-rate system would have the overall effect of lowering residential property taxes for all groups except for large lot properties with multifamily housing receiving the largest tax breaks. While tax burdens would be shifted to nonresidential properties, especially those with underutilized land uses, Gihring states that development patterns would likely experience little short-term change due to the relatively similar land values of urban and exurban properties in Clark County as well as the area’s strong land value appreciation trends. Future effectiveness is suggested to be contingent on the effective integration of land value taxation with effective regulatory mechanisms.

list-item.p: 109. Greenberg, M., P. Craighill, H. Mayer, C. Zukin, and J. Wells. 2001. “Brownfield Redevelopment and Affordable Housing: A Case Study of New Jersey.” Housing Policy Debate 12 (3): 515–40.

sec.p: This article analyzes the results of a 2000 telephone survey of 779 random samples from New Jersey adults to answer questions of what proportion of the New Jersey population is willing to move to cleaned up brownfields within five years, what are their demographic characteristics, and what incentives are most likely to encourage these moves. According to the survey, 36 percent of its respondents plan to move, 22 percent are willing to move if offered an incentive, and the remaining will not move. Persons who are relatively young, economically disadvantaged, and interested in becoming homeowners are more willing to relocate. Other willing-to-move groups include affluent young, childless, or middle class Latino and Asian American households. Conversely, persons identified to be “empty-nesters” exemplified very low levels of willingness to relocate to redeveloped brownfield sites. Confidence in former brownfields to be clean, safe, and capable of maintaining property values is identified as an important factor in motivating people to relocate to former brownfield sites sites. Incentives for development of affordable housing in such sites are also identified as a strong policy concern.

list-item.p: 110. Nelson, A. C. 2000. “Effects of Urban Containment on Housing Prices and Landowner Behavior.” Land Lines 12 (3): 1–3.
Keywords: affordability, Atlanta (Georgia), Portland (Oregon), housing price, smart growth, urban growth boundary, zoning

sec.p: Urban containment policies can assist in meeting smart growth goals, but also limit land supplies and raise housing prices. To investigate the dynamics of this phenomenon and to guide future research, a comparison between Portland, a city with urban containment, and Atlanta, a city without urban containment, is considered. In the early 1990s, while Atlanta experienced a 20 percent increase in housing prices, prices in Portland rose by 60 percent. However, the portion of household income contributed to housing remained the same for both cities. Homeownership and perceived quality of housing increased in Portland, but not in Atlanta. Remarking that affordability is a serious concern in practically all US cities regardless of growth management, smart growth, or urban containment policies, Nelson states that urban containment presents a new regime in planning that raises concerns about land speculation and housing affordability. Strategies for mitigating these affordability issues include location efficient mortgages and a property tax structure that penalizes owners for holding land for speculation.

sec.title: 2. Planning
sec.p:
111. Burchell, R. W., D. Listokin, and C. C. Galley. 2000. “Smart Growth: More than a Ghost of Urban Policy Past, Less than a Bold New Horizon.” Housing Policy Debate 11 (4): 821–79.
Keywords: affordability, infill, revitalization, segregation, smart growth
Through reviewing the origins, costs, and benefits of smart growth, Burchell et al. provide an extensive discussion of smart growth within the context of past urban policy and new planning frontiers. In terms of housing, they state that increasing populations of empty-nesters, young professionals, and immigrants provide a strong demand for the types of housing patterns promoted through smart growth principles. Furthermore, current housing policies that encourage the mobility of low-income minority populations may also provide an outlet for central city housing stocks to be freed up for revitalization. Therefore, planning mechanisms such as urban infill and redevelopment, as well as the development of more environmentally efficient suburbs, provide a prime opportunity to offer all socioeconomic groups greater housing choices. Burchell et al. also consider the potential fiscal savings of smart growth development patterns and discuss the findings of smart growth studies conducted by Rutgers University in the 1990s. According to this review, the United States could potentially save up to 250 billion dollars in twenty-five years if smart growth principles were applied to mainstream development practices. Therefore, not only would a more diverse housing stock be achieved, but a projected savings of $5,790 per unit of housing may also be realized.

list-item.p: 112. Chakraborty, A., G. Knapp, D. Nguyen, and J. H. Shin. 2010. “The Effects of High-Density Zoning on Multifamily Housing Construction in the Suburbs of Six US Metropolitan Areas.” Urban Studies 47 (2): 437–51.

sec.p: In the article, the authors focus on the relation between zoning constraint and multi-family house constructions in six metropolitan areas over 1990–2000. These six metropolitan areas are Portland (OR), Boston (MA), Miami-Dade County (FL), Minneapolis-St Paul (MN), Sacramento (CA), and Washington, DC. In order to eliminate the endogeneity due to the interaction between zoning and housing constructions, a two-stage least square method was used. Level of zoning constraint in jurisdictions across the six metropolitans was first evaluated based on 1960 demographic and economic information, and an instrumental variable for zoning was created. This zoning instrument was then utilized as an explanatory variable for change of multifamily housing units in each jurisdiction. The research has some interesting observations. High-density development is less likely to occur in a zoning for white neighborhoods that are father away for the central business area. Areas zoned as high-density uses tend to have greater increase of multifamily units.

list-item.p: 113. Danielsen, K. A., R. E. Lang, and W. Fulton. 1999. “Retracting suburbia: Smart Growth and the Future of Housing.” Housing Policy Debate 10 (3): 513–40.

sec.p: This article provides an analytic review of connections between housing and smart growth. The authors ascertain that successful smart growth policies should not only limit and restrict certain growth but also include opportunities for new development. This article particularly focuses on the way American consumers of housing view density. Changing demographics, especially increases in single and childless households, suggest impending need for more diverse housing types that can be achieved through higher density residential landscapes. Market research studies from the late 1990s show that preconceived negative notions about high-density development are an obstacle for higher density developments. To overcome such challenges, the authors propose measures to make higher density housing more attractive, such as considerations for parking, security, and privacy, as well as constructing high density homes with the same levels of amenities and qualities as traditional suburban homes. Smart growth friendly financing alternatives for both developers and consumers are also identified as ways to make higher density development more attractive.

list-item.p: 114. Edwards, M. M., and A. Haines. 2007. “Evaluating Smart Growth: Implications for Small Communities.” Journal of Planning Education and Research 27: 49–64.

sec.p: In their assessment of smart growth implementation within Wisconsin’s local comprehensive plans, Edwards and Haines concentrate on six overarching goals of smart growth planning including community development, natural resource preservation, transportation choice, economic development, planning, and housing. Housing issues are thus considerably evaluated in this study. In their analysis, the authors find that 73 percent of Wisconsin comprehensive plans comprehensively addressed housing and 23 percent narrowly addressed housing, primarily focusing on enhancing variety, proximity to work and shopping, accommodation for the elderly, and affordability. However, findings also suggested that comprehensive plans did not address variety with wide enough of a scope, and few considered inclusionary zoning as a means of reaching its housing goals.

list-item.p: 115. Jepson, E. J. Jr. 2004. “Human Nature and Sustainable Development: A Strategic Challenge for Planners.” Journal of Planning Literature 19 (1): 3–15.

sec.p: While sustainability, as well as its concerns for economy, environment, and equity, has been a popular concept in recent planning literature, a void is often found between it and actual planning practices. Jepson addresses this void and considers how the traditional “expansionist” view has prevailed over sustainability as the dominant ideology in land use and then offers insights to assist planners interested in promoting more sustainable planning solutions. While the expansionist view is accommodating to the human tendency to manipulate and exploit nature, Jepson states that this neoclassical economic view does not always accurately account for the true costs and benefits of certain land use decisions. Through modifying this ideology and through revising the notion of discounting and other economic views, environmental sustainability can be integrated into mainstream paradigms. To advance to this goal, Jepson provides recommendations including encouraging planners to reflect on their own values and preferences in order to become better facilitators of sustainability and make a long-term dedication to educating other on the benefits of sustainability.

list-item.p: 116. Glaeser, E. L., J. Gyourko, and R. E. Saks. 2005. “Why Have Housing Price Gone Up?” The American Economic Review 95 (2): 329–33.
Keywords: housing price, land use regulation, zoning

sec.p: Stating that housing market constraints are highly related to changing land use regulation patterns, Glaeser et al. consider the welfare impacts of such regulations as they pertain to housing costs. Through an economic location model, the authors state that a certain optimal level of development for a town’s current residents may not be the optimal in the future. These existing homeowners have a strong incentive to increase their housing values, but such increases have an adverse effect for those not owning homes. Residential preferences are also considered in terms of how they interact with the decisions of zoning authorities and developers. Demonstrated through another economic model which represents how the zoning authority is influenced by development interests, with developers tending to lobby with the resource of cash, and homeowners with the resource of time. This model is further used to explain how the changing preferences of decision makers may be attributable to the increasing influence of a growing number of homeowners and how this influence may have contributed to greater levels of regulation and subsequently higher housing prices.

list-item.p: 117. Whitehead, C. M. E. 2007. “Planning Policies and Affordable Housing: England as a Successful Case Study?” Housing Studies 22 (1): 25–44.
Keywords: affordability, housing price, public housing, land use planning, United Kingdom

sec.p: Exploring linkages between land-use planning and affordable housing in England, Whitehead poses the questions of how planning policy is aligned with affordable housing goals, what have been the successes of this system, and how the English system may serve as a lesson to other nations. While Whitehead acknowledges that virtually all types of land use regulation will increase housing prices, she justifies a relationship between planning and affordability through arguments that government should serve as an equitable distributor of resources and increased property values resulting from regulation can be translated into opportunities to fund affordable housing. Throughout the twentieth century, England’s system has evolved from one that largely involved localized control of social housing that was separate from national land-use goals to a more integrated system that has grown to include requirements for the proportional development of affordable housing (housing elements). Whitehead acknowledges that the program has successfully increased the number of affordable housing units, directing efforts to the locations where they are most needed, with a shift to more diverse patterns of affordable housing tenure. However, affordable housing issues such as decreases in publicly provided housing are noted as problematic areas. Whitehead points out that land-use planning alone is not likely to be an adequate provider of affordable housing. According to him, this system vests the central government with strong powers over land-use decisions in comparison with other countries which have granted greater property rights to the private market. However, growing desires to shift affordable housing provision to the private sector demonstrate strong links between planning in England and other countries, such as the United States.

list-item.p: 118. Wood, G., M. Berry, E. Taylor, and C. Nygaard. 2008. “Community Mix, Affordable Housing and Metropolitan Planning Strategy in Melbourne.” Built Environment 34 (3): 273–90.

sec.p: This article focuses on the Melbourne 2030 strategic plan that intends to make Melbourne a more compact city with a growth boundary. Within the city there will be twenty-five Principal Activity Centers (PAC) that will act as multi-use, transit-oriented hubs. There is great concern in the government that low-income individuals and families will not be able to live in or around these centers and this will lead to a lack good community mix. In order to evaluate whether this is going to happen, Wood et al. studied spatial trends of affordable housing in the Melbourne region over 1990–2003. They suggested that affordability policies of the 2030 strategic plan may only have limited impacts on a few people to live in or around PACs. Market reliance is not helping low-income people find affordable housing. More government involvement in the form of stronger planning measures may be required to keep a healthy community mix around PACs.

sec.title: 3. Administrative and Legislative Supports
sec.p:
119. Aurand, A. G. 2007. “Is Smart Growth Smart for Low-Income Households? A Study of the Impact of the Four Smart Growth Principles and the Supply of Affordable Housing.” PhD diss. University of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
Keywords: affordability, Baltimore (Maryland), multifamily housing, Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), Portland (Oregon), Seattle (Washington), smart growth
Aurand’s dissertation considers neighborhood density, housing variety, mixed land use, and public open space as four primary principles of smart growth and considers their implications on affordable housing supplies. He studies various growth management policies of Portland, Baltimore, Seattle, and Philadelphia. Using US Census and a range of other national data, separate regression analyses for the years of 1990 and 2000 are integrated into Aurand’s quasi-experimental research design. Weak evidence suggests that urban containment policies may reduce the availability of open space for low-income multifamily housing structures. Density is found to be moderately associated with more affordable housing for low-income populations, and the supply of multifamily housing is found to have a strong positive relationship with affordable housing. Aurnand concludes that this evidence supports a call for smart growth policies to address multifamily housing supply issues because higher densities alone will not foster affordable housing options. He also recommends that state, regional, and local policies should be implemented to address affordability through tools, such as density bonuses, inclusionary zoning, housing trust funds, and zoning code easements.

list-item.p: 120. Bogdon, A. S. 2003. “Monitoring Housing Affordability.” Land Market Monitoring for Smart Urban Growth, edited by G. J. Knaap. Cambridge, MA: Lincoln Institute of Land Policy.

sec.p: Noting the potential of smart growth to increase land and housing prices, Bogdon presents this chapter as an argument for localities to monitor the affects of such policies on affordability and provides an analysis of the methodological issues involved with making such evaluations. According to Bogdon, the primary reason for monitoring affordability is to ensure that that the benefits of smart growth may outweigh its costs, and that such costs are equitably distributed in a way that does not unfairly burden low-income households. Housing affordability is commonly established by a 30 percent of income threshold for consuming housing services. However, this measure is critiqued on the grounds that different income groups will be able to devote varying percentages of income to housing. The issue is further complicated by the issue of homeownership due to the fact that homeownership costs represent both the consumption of housing and an investment in real estate. Classification of income groups, Housing and Urban Development (HUD) fair market rents, and shelter poverty standards, which measure the amount of income available for housing minus the costs of all other goods and services necessary to sustain an adequate standard of living, are suggested as alternatives as well as measures that may be combined with housing percentage measures. Bogdon also suggests a number of data sources for conducting affordability evaluations, including decennial census data, the American Community Survey, and American housing surveys as well as locally collected primary and administrative data.

list-item.p: 121. Boyle, R., and R. Mohamed. 2007. “State Growth Management, Smart Growth and Urban Containment: A Review of the U.S. and a Study of the Heartland.” Journal of Environmental Planning and Management 50 (5): 677–97.

sec.p: Recognizing that much growth management, smart growth, and urban containment research focuses on states with such policies, Boyle and Mohamed present this case study of Michigan to exemplify how growth management has failed in a state which has not enacted statewide mandates. The authors find that while county and local efforts have been made, an absence of strong and consistent measures has prevented smart growth goals, such as urban containment and affordable housing, to be achieved. Statewide incentive programs, such as the Cool Cities and Brownfields Redevelopment initiatives, have been used to promote smart growth goals in Michigan. However, these programs are fragmented and have had questionable impacts on neighborhoods and regions. According to Boyle and Mohamed, these shortcomings are likely to be present in other states and will not likely be overcome without comprehensive state mandates that focus on regional planning initiatives.

list-item.p: 122. Burges, G., and S. Monk. 2008. “Delivering Affordable Housing through the Planning System: Challenges and Good Practice.” Housing, Care and Support 11 (3): 4–8.
Keywords: affordable housing, United Kingdom, legislation

sec.p: In this article, the authors discussed how England promotes affordable housing by Section 106 (S106) of the Town and Country Planning Act in England. S106 requires contractual agreements between developers and local planning authorities on how many units in a particular development should be set aside as affordable housing. The authors conducted a study involving email and phone interviews, and case studies of five local planning authorities. The authors found that the amount of affordable housing being delivered through S106 has been increasing. It is difficult to discern how they come to this conclusion because they offer no real empirical data to back up this claim. The evidence they presented seems to be heavily anecdotal. The authors concluded the article with a lengthy list of the “best practices” embraced by the regions featured in the study.

list-item.p: 123. Freilich, R. H., and N. M. Popowitz. 2010. “The Umbrella of Sustainability: Smart Growth, New Urbanism, Renewable Energy and Green Development in the 21st Century.” The Urban Lawyer 42 (1): 1–39.

sec.p: Robert and Popowitz interpreted sustainability as an umbrella term covering four areas: smart growth, new urbanism, renewable energy, and green development. They thought that the growth management in California has all the four elements. What makes the article valuable is the review about the legal efforts for promoting smart growth. After the 1972 Golden v. Planning Board of the Town of Ramapo case, growth management gained its constitutionality, and began to gain it popularity. In California, management efforts can be traced back to the 1970s, primarily focusing on management of environmental impacts. After 2000, a series of legislative activities are observed to provide legal supports for smart growth. In 2002, in addition to the State Planning Law, the Assembly Bill 857 was adopted to create development priority areas to guide state infrastructure investment and other expenditures, and therefore, to improve land-use efficiency. The Global Warming Solutions of 2006 provided stricter regulation on gas emissions. Finally, the Senate Bill 375 (i.e., the Sustainable Communities Strategy Act) was adopted in 2008, which gave the state government direct authority over local and regional land-use decisions.

list-item.p: 124. Kiel, K. A. 2005. “Environmental Regulations and the Housing Market: A Review of the Literature.” Cityscape: A Journal of Policy Development and Research 8 (1): 187–207.

sec.p: This broad review of studies examining the relationship between environmental regulations and the housing market addresses the impacts of a large range of policies including air regulations, water and wetlands regulations, the Endangered Species Act, coastal zone regulations, toxic waste regulations, and growth controls. According to Kiel, although few of these laws are directed at the housing market, they have the potential to both directly and indirectly increase the costs of housing. While the author states that regulation has been demonstrated to increase the cost of housing, she also makes a number of methodological and theoretical critiques. Kiel notes that the regression methods commonly used to identify such impacts are often deficient in their consideration of labor market effects as well as the constantly changing dynamics of the housing market. Furthermore, Kiel states that little has been done to identify whether the nature of price increases are supply or demand based. To better weigh the consequences of environmental policy, Kiel calls for a cost–benefit analysis approach to determine appropriate balances between environmental regulation and affordable housing.

list-item.p: 125. McGee, H. W., Jr. 2000. “Equity and Efficacy in Washington State’s GMA Affordable Housing Goal.” Washington University Journal of Law and Policy 3: 539–53.
Keywords: affordability, growth management, Washington, zoning

sec.p: This article describes the Washington State Growth Management Act (GMA) and its subsequent implications. While the GMA includes a provision of “fair share” affordable housing, its housing goals are ill-defined. Although the GMA places undeniable importance on affordable housing, it is inefficient and ineffective because of structural problems, including parochialism and governmental fragmentation that does not allow housing to be addressed on a regional basis. McGee also notes that legislative efforts to cope with this issue have been met with opposition by both economic interests and local governmental concerns for maintaining autonomy. Stating that smart growth legislation in many regards is ill-suited to address affordability issues, McGee advocates for more comprehensive policies that integrate the issues of housing stock conditions, employment, education security, and social services, as well as regional polices with stronger provisions for inclusionary zoning, incentive zoning, density bonuses, and regional emphasis of local zoning decisions.

list-item.p: 126. Talen, E. 2012. “Prospects for Walkable, Mixed-Income Neighborhoods: Insights from U.S. Developers.” Journal of Housing and the Built Environment. Accessed June 6, 2012. doi:10.1007/s10901-012-9290-9.

sec.p: This article is based on a survey of fifty-four developers (who promote walkable neighborhood) across the United States (with 63 percent response rate) and reports developers’ view about affordability. The survey reveals that smaller residential units and better floor design are the two most practical approaches to promote affordability, and tax credits and density bonuses are the financial tools. Most of these developers point out that the existing land-use regulatory system and the financial regulations pose barriers to promoting affordability. Local land-use regulations “discriminate in housing form,” and it is difficult to get mixed-use and mixed-income development financed. Based on all these, Talen concludes that it is necessary to reform the existing financing and land-use control systems. Agencies and institutions in the public and private sectors should all be involved to create better communications, and possibly to create partnership and to issue a “model affordability code.”

For instance, the Housing Assistant Grant Program of the HUD promotes housing affordability for low-income families. Income is one of the criteria in grant allocation.
